instruction: If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.
input: Hello doctor,I had mumps five months ago and after that, I started to have an infection in my left testes. It was swollen and now it has shrunk to almost half the size of the other one. As I am sexually active, I feel a pain in each of the vas deferens after sex. If I do not have sex for days, they become sensitive. I was treated with Ceftum 500 mg, the first time I had an infection. Now my question is, is there any chance that the infection is still in my body? And, do I need to get examined for it? For the time being, please suggest some precautionary antibiotics for my relief.
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:
Hello doctor,I had mumps five months ago and after that, I started to have an infection in my left testes. It was swollen and now it has shrunk to almost half the size of the other one. As I am sexually active, I feel a pain in each of the vas deferens after sex. If I do not have sex for days, they become sensitive. I was treated with Ceftum 500 mg, the first time I had an infection. Now my question is, is there any chance that the infection is still in my body? And, do I need to get examined for it? For the time being, please suggest some precautionary antibiotics for my relief.

### Response:Based on the description you provided, it seems like you are experiencing post-mumps orchitis, which is an infection of the testicles following mumps. The swelling and shrinkage of the testicle are common symptoms of this condition.

Regarding the infection still being present in your body, it is possible that the infection has not been completely cleared. In some cases, mumps orchitis can lead to chronic epididymitis, which is characterized by recurrent episodes of inflammation in the epididymis (the tube that carries sperm from the testicle).

To determine if the infection is still present, I would recommend seeking medical attention from a healthcare professional, such as a urologist or infectious disease specialist. They will be able to evaluate your symptoms, perform any necessary tests (such as a physical examination, blood tests, or cultures), and provide appropriate treatment if needed.

In the meantime, to alleviate your symptoms and provide relief, you can consider taking antibiotics as prescribed by your healthcare provider. However, it is important to note that antibiotics alone may not be sufficient to treat the underlying cause of the infection.

Please consult with a healthcare professional for further evaluation and guidance.

### Response:Hello,

The answer to your first question is that you should wait for at least three months after using cocaine before trying to conceive. This is because it takes approximately three months for the majority of cocaine to be eliminated from the body.

Regarding the duration of cocaine in sperm, it is estimated that cocaine can remain present in semen for up to 48 hours after use. However, it's important to note that the concentration of cocaine in semen may decrease over time.

I would strongly recommend seeking counseling and support from a healthcare professional or a reproductive specialist who can provide personalized guidance based on your specific circumstances. They can help assess any potential risks and provide appropriate advice regarding conception and drug use.

### Response:As a doctor, I would recommend the following precautions for your son with myopia (nearsightedness):

1. Encourage regular eye exams: It is important to have his eyes examined by an optometrist or an ophthalmologist at least once a year, or more frequently if there are any concerns or changes in his vision.

2. Ensure proper lighting: Make sure the lighting in his bedroom and other areas he spends time in is adequate and not too bright or dim. This can help reduce eyestrain and strain on the eyes.

3. Limit screen time: Encourage him to take regular breaks from close-up activities such as watching TV, playing video games, or using electronic devices. This can help prevent excessive eye strain and promote eye health.

4. Wear protective eyewear: When participating in activities that involve potential eye injuries, such as sports or hobbies like woodworking, ensure he wears appropriate protective eyewear to safeguard his eyes.

5. Maintain good posture: Teach him proper posture and ergonomics to minimize strain on his eyes and body. This includes sitting up straight, maintaining a neutral spine, and avoiding excessive bending or tilting of the head.

6. Promote out

### Input:
Hi doctor,I had sex for the first time. After that, I did not get my periods yet. I went to a gynecologist. She had taken my blood sample and it was negative. But, still I have not gotten my periods and it has been a week ahead. What could be the reason for my late periods?

### Response:There could be several reasons for late periods. One possible cause is a delay in ovulation, which can occur due to various factors such as stress, changes in sleep patterns, or hormonal imbalances. Another potential reason is an ectopic pregnancy, where fertilization occurs outside of the uterus. Additionally, certain medical conditions like polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) or thyroid disorders can also contribute to irregular or missed periods.

To determine the exact cause of your late periods, it is important to consult with your gynecologist again. They may recommend further tests, such as hormone level checks or imaging studies, to help identify the underlying issue. It is also essential to provide your gynecologist with a detailed description of your symptoms and any other relevant information. They will be able to provide you with a more accurate diagnosis and appropriate treatment plan based on their evaluation.

The immediate side effects of phenol poisoning include irritation of the throat and stomach, vomiting, and increased salivation. Other symptoms that may occur later include breathing difficulties, irregular heartbeat, seizures, coma, and even death.

It is important to seek immediate medical attention for your friend. Intravenous fluids may be administered to maintain hydration and electrolyte balance.

instruction: If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.
input: Hello doctor,I am a 50-year-old female who has had an elevated ferritin level for many years now. My last ferritin level was 342, 20 days back. My ferritin level has been as high as 390. My TIBC, UIBC, iron, and iron saturation have always been within normal range. My glucose has always ranged from 100 to 104. I was tested for hemochromatosis and results are negative. My doctors keep telling me that we will just watch my ferritin level and I have bloodwork done every six months. I was diagnosed with fibromyalgia last year. I am looking for some answers and some help.
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:
Hello doctor,I am a 50-year-old female who has had an elevated ferritin level for many years now. My last ferritin level was 342, 20 days back. My ferritin level has been as high as 390. My TIBC, UIBC, iron, and iron saturation have always been within normal range. My glucose has always ranged from 100 to 104. I was tested for hemochromatosis and results are negative. My doctors keep telling me that we will just watch my ferritin level and I have bloodwork done every six months. I was diagnosed with fibromyalgia last year. I am looking for some answers and some help.

### Response:Based on the information provided, it seems that you have a chronically elevated ferritin level. Ferritin is a protein that stores iron in the body, and high levels can indicate iron overload conditions such as hemochromatosis. However, since your TIBC (total iron-binding capacity), UIBC (unbound iron-binding capacity), iron, and iron saturation levels are all within normal range, it suggests that your elevated ferritin level may not be due to hemochromatosis.

Given that your doctors have already ruled out hemochromatosis, it is important to consider other potential causes for your elevated ferritin level. One possibility is that your chronically elevated ferritin level could be related to another condition, such as inflammation or certain medications.

To further investigate the cause of your elevated ferritin level, I would recommend discussing your symptoms and test results with a rheumatologist or a specialist in iron disorders. They can provide a more comprehensive evaluation and consider additional diagnostic tests if necessary.

In the meantime, it is important to monitor your symptoms closely and communicate any changes or new developments with your healthcare provider. They will be able to guide you further based on your individual situation.

4. Maintain a healthy lifestyle: Eat a balanced diet, exercise regularly, and manage stress levels. A strong immune system can help fight off infe

instruction: If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.
input: Hi doctor,I am a 25-year-old male. I do not have any medical history. Been always healthy. For the past 3 months, I have been experiencing this facial tightness which comes pretty often throughout the day with different intensity. The facial tension usually comes half an hour after I leave the bed. The tightness on my face happens to be on both sides of my face but usually more intense on the right. At times, I can feel it from my neck all the way up to my face. As of recent, I have been feeling this slight burning sensation on my chest to my shoulders as well. Prior to this facial tightness, I have been suffering from this burning feeling on the centre of my chest for about a month. It was my first time experiencing heartburn and I thought it was heart related. Went for X-rays and echo heart ultrasound. Everything came out fine. I have a healthy heart. What made the burning chest sensation go away temporarily is lying down, eating, exercising and drinking alcohol. And the weird part is the same thing helps me relieve my facial tightness temporarily is the same thing as that for the burning chest sensation; lying down, eating, exercising and drinking alcohol.Since having this facial tightness, I have paid numerous visits to different doctors, even the neuro-specialist and they all said it was anxiety. The doctors did facial senses test where they take a piece of fine cotton to touch different parts of my face. I had to close my eyes and tell them where the spot is. I have no troubles at all. I did blood test. It came out normal. They told me I do not need to do any scans and that it was merely anxiety and it will go off by itself. I convinced myself that I had anxiety because of the one month heartburn ordeal that I was suffering from. Even though the facial tightness was there, I tried my utmost best to ignore it. I do not think that I have any anxiety in me now as I try not to think of the weird tightness sensation. However, it has been 3 whole months and now I am getting alarmed and worried that it is still here and with newer sensations as I described above. In all honesty, I do feel that the intensity of the facial tension as compared to I first experienced it, is less. However, it is always there even as when I am typing this. I do not see any physical change on my body. Not sure if it is neuro damage. I am worried sick.Hope I can get some form of advice and diagnosis.

instruction: If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.
input: Hello doctor,My mother is 75 years old. She had been treated for TB (tuberculosis) of the abdomen as her ultrasound of abdomen finding was thicken bowel loop. In general terms, it was informed about TB in her abdomen. Accordingly, medicines were given to her as per the advise of a local MD doctor. Treatment continued for three months and due to some discontinuation of medicine it relapsed and again she was diagnosed with Thicken bowel loop as per USG. Again treatment continued.However, while undergoing treatment she lost sensation in her legs and complained of losing sensation in her legs and numbness in her feet and was unable to put on slippers in her feet with difficulty in moving. She also complained that while moving she felt as if she was moving on a bed of soft cotton.Subsequent treatment by neuro experts revealed that overdose of treatment of her TB in abdomen resulted in this condition and she was diagnosed for peripheral neuropathy and was advised for biopsy for proper diagnosis. Meanwhile, she fell and hurt herself which was later on diagnosed that her spine at L3 - L4 was compressed due to felling abruptly and accordingly she was advised to take bed rest for three months. Slowly, she recovered from this condition felt pain in her back and was facing another kind of problem as she could not sit for a longer time and preferred to lay down on the bed.Finding her bad condition subsequetly, we also took consultation from other neuro experts at a prestigious institution where she was prescribed Lupivitin one tablet and Sammy one tablet.When condition persisted thereafter she was given Primosa one tablet daily, Neurox one tablet daily, Maxglobin 50 mg one tablet and Defart 6 mg.But, whenever she was given medicine her condition further aggravated. After about six months of treatment by the neuro expert, she has now been referred to the department of immunology for their advice. Meanwhile, we also took advice from a rheumatologist who diagnosed a kind of arthritis and started treating accordingly. He also started the course of Defzacort (steroid) along with other medicines. The steroid was prescribed with a decreasing dose per week from 60 mg per day to 6 mg per day.However, after taking about two months of steroid course her condition deteriorated and had severe breathlessness. Her blood sugar level also shot up and ultimately she was hospitalized and the treatment of steroid withdrawn. After 15 days of treatment at the hospital she recovered to her previous condition. But, her neuro problem of numbness in her legs and loss of sensation in legs still continues. Please help.

instruction: If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.
input: Hello doctor,My son has developed anxiety symptoms about four years ago. They came completely out of the blue. He was with someone who now has heart palpitations, sweaty palms and feet, and lightheadedness sitting in the living room. We ran a battery of tests when it first happened including TSH, EKG, lung scans, blood panels, etc. and everything was normal. So we went down the path of anxiety. Four years later, the symptoms continued. As my son now has a terrible fear of doctors, we tried a home blood test to get a full thyroid panel. I have attached the results.The blood work came back normal. Low normal TSH, but low normal T4 and lower normal free T4 and free T3. There is nothing that shows an abnormality. However, his urine test showed moderately low iodine and slightly low selenium. I have read that abnormalities in these measures could cause thyroid problems. What am I wondering is if these two indicators are worth further exploration with an endocrinologist knowing that going to the doctor will cause my son a severe panic.Also, is it possible that low iodine could have been a temporary diet thing and it is masking the signs of hyperthyroidism in the blood work? He has all of the symptoms of someone with hyperthyroidism. On a side note, I am hypothyroid, my sister is hypothyroid and my two nieces had Hashimoto\s with my younger niece having thyroid cancer and got her thyroid removed at age of 22. So everyone on my side of the family has thyroid issues. We were wondering if you could please give us some guidance. Looking to see if we need to eliminate thyroid as a possible cause of his symptoms or if it is worth further pursuit.

Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

He has all of the symptoms of someone with hyperthyroidism. On a side note, I am hypothyroid, my sister is hypothyroid and my two nieces had Hashimoto\s with my younger niece having thyroid cancer and got her thyroid removed at age of 22. ### Response:Based on the information provided, it seems that your son has been experiencing anxiety symptoms for the past four years. The symptoms came out of the blue and have persisted over time.

The initial battery of tests conducted to rule out any underlying medical conditions did not reveal any abnormalities in thyroid function. However, the recent blood work showed slightly low normal levels of T4 and free T4, indicating possible thyroid dysfunction.

The low normal TSH level suggests that the thyroid gland is producing enough thyroid hormones, but the levels of T4 and free T4 are still below the normal range. This pattern is consistent with primary hypothyroidism, where there is an issue with the thyroid gland itself rather than a problem with the pituitary gland or hypothalamus regulating thyroid function.

input: Hi doctor,My wisdom tooth present in the lower left region is growing. I have a sufficient space for it to grow, and it is growing straight. I do not have pain in the tooth and half of the tooth is poking out now. But I have trouble in opening my mouth fully.
raw_output:

Hi doctor,My wisdom tooth present in the lower left region is growing. I have a sufficient space for it to grow, and it is growing straight. I do not have pain in the tooth and half of the tooth is poking out now. But I have trouble in opening my mouth fully.

### Response:Based on the description you provided, it seems like you are experiencing some discomfort due to the growth of your lower left wisdom tooth. Here are some possible scenarios:

1. Impacted Wisdom Tooth: It is possible that the wisdom tooth is impacted, meaning it is partially or completely trapped within the gum tissue or bone. This can lead to pain, swelling, infection, and difficulty in opening your mouth fully.

2. Crowding: If the wisdom tooth is growing straight but there is insufficient space for it to erupt properly, it can cause crowding of the other teeth. This can result in discomfort, pain, and difficulty in chewing.

3. Cyst or Abscess: In some cases, an impacted wisdom tooth can develop into a cyst or abscess, which is an infected sac-like structure filled with fluid or pus. This can cause severe pain, swelling, and potentially affect your overall oral health.

To determine the exact cause of your symptoms and provide appropriate treatment, it is important to visit a dentist or an oral surgeon. They will evaluate your condition through a physical examination, X-rays, and possibly additional tests. Treatment options may include extraction of the impacted wisdom tooth, orthodontic realignment, or oral surgery procedures depending

### Response:Based on the symptoms you have described, it is possible that you may have a condition called hemolytic anemia. Hemolytic anemia occurs when red blood cells are destroyed faster than they can be replaced, leading to a decrease in the number of red blood cells in the body.

Hereditary spherocytosis is one type of hemolytic anemia. In this condition, the red blood cells are shaped like spheres and are more prone to destruction. The symptoms you mentioned, such as yellowing of the eyes (jaundice), fatigue, easy bruising, and irregular menstrual cycles, can be associated with hereditary spherocytosis.

However, it is important to note that a misdiagnosis is always possible. It would be best to consult with a hematologist who can review your medical history, perform a physical examination, and order any necessary tests to confirm the diagnosis. They will be able to provide you with a definitive answer and develop an appropriate treatment plan based on your specific situation.

I have been diagnosed with candida and dysbiosis but my regular doctor does not seem to know what is wrong with me. I have been very stressed and have suffered anxiety since I was about 16. I was not on any medications and started taking Cymbalta a few months ago.After about three to four days, I started to notice a bit of burning in my feet. I have since stopped taking the Cymbalta about a month ago. My feet seemed fine. Then seven days ago, I have started getting really bad pain in my feet and burning and tickling and pins and needle feelings. I am not diabetic or alcoholic. I have no idea what has brought this on or whether it can be reversed. I am so stressed out. I have to be on my feet for my job for about four and a half hours every morning. Can this be tested to see if the nerve cells are either dead or just damaged and can it be reversed? This feels like it is going to ruin my life. Please help.

The symptoms described, such as burning feet, pain, tingling, and numbness, are common manifestations of peripheral neuropathy. These symptoms can occur in various conditions, including diabetes, alcoholism, vitamin deficiencies, and certain medications.

Since the patient mentioned that they have been diagnosed with candida and dysbiosis, it is important to consider if these conditions could be contributing factors. However, it is also possible that the symptoms are unrelated to these conditions and may be due to an underlying issue not yet identified.

To further evaluate the patient's condition, a thorough medical history, physical examination, and possibly some diagnostic tests may be necessary. These tests may include nerve conduction studies, blood tests, and possibly imaging studies such as an MRI or CT scan.

input: Hi doctor,I have blood dots present under my skin. But it appears only in my arms. I have them on a different arm every morning. I do not have itching, and they are not raised.

### Response:Based on the description you provided, the blood dots present under your skin could be a condition called petechiae. Petechiae are small, red or purple spots on the skin that occur when there is bleeding in the tiny blood vessels just below the surface of the skin.

The fact that you have them in your arms and they appear different each morning suggests that they may be related to a localized issue in your arms rather than a systemic condition.

Since you do not have itching and the spots are not raised, it is less likely to be a symptom of an infectious disease such as viral exanthems or scabies. However, it is important to consider other possible causes such as vasculitis, coagulopathies, or even certain medications.

To further evaluate the cause of your blood dots, I recommend scheduling an appointment with a dermatologist or primary care physician. They will be able to conduct a thorough examination, take a detailed medical history, and order any necessary tests to determine the underlying cause of your petechiae.

input: Hello doctor,I had a silent missed abortion last year in the third month of my pregnancy. After that, I got some tests done, which resulted in CMV IgG positive. Then I got vaccinated for rubella to prevent any casualties in the next pregnancy. Now I want to try and conceive, but just now I got my torch panel done again. And now the HSV IGM is positive with 1.15 range along with CMV and rubella IgG positive. Should I wait or can I try to conceive right now? My husband\s torch panel also done, nothing abnormal.I am currently under Folic acid and Multivitamin, for now, to conceive faster. And also a homeopathic medicine for migraine.
raw_output:

### Instruction:

### Input:
Hello doctor,I had a silent missed abortion last year in the third month of my pregnancy. After that, I got some tests done, which resulted in CMV IgG positive. Then I got vaccinated for rubella to prevent any casualties in the next pregnancy. Now I want to try and conceive, but just now I got my torch panel done again. And now the HSV IGM is positive with 1.15 range along with CMV and rubella IgG positive. Should I wait or can I try to conceive right now? My husband\s torch panel also done, nothing abnormal.I am currently under Folic acid and Multivitamin, for now, to conceive faster. And also a homeopathic medicine for migraine.

### Response:Based on the information provided, it seems that you have a history of a silent miscarriage in the third month of pregnancy and you have tested positive for CMV IgG, HSV IGM, and rubella IgG. Additionally, your torch panel showed positive results for HSV IGM and CMV.

Given this information, it is important to consider the potential risks associated with these infections during pregnancy. CMV (Cytomegalovirus) can cause birth defects, especially in the first trimester. HSV (Herpes Simplex Virus) can also be transmitted to the baby during vaginal delivery if the mother is infected. Rubella (German Measles) can cause birth defects if contracted during pregnancy.

Considering these risks, it is recommended that you consult with your healthcare provider before trying to conceive. They will be able to assess your individual situation and provide personalized advice based on factors such as the severity of the infections, your overall health, and any previous pregnancies or deliveries.

In the meantime, it is important to continue taking folic acid and multivitamins to support a healthy pregnancy.

input: Hello doctor,Around a year ago, some red pimples started appearing around my mouth, chin, forehead, and my nose. These small red pimples create a red area when seen from far away because they are very small and inflamed. It never disappears. My skin always feels stuck and not flexible and with a mildly itchy or burning sensation. No matter how much moisturizer I apply, it does not help. I am using Eucerin atopic control moisturizer and a gel cleanser with Hyaluronan. I even tried using Metronidazole and tea oil, but again it did not help. I have also tried to stop using anything on my face for some days, but it stayed the same. I am 24 years old now, and I never had acne tendencies when I was a teenager, and my skin always looked very smooth. My birth control pill is still the same as it was when I first started taking it, which wad around ten years ago. I do not use steroid creams nor fluoride toothpaste. How can I get rid of this? It was not there before a year. I am attaching a picture of my face. Thanks.

It was not there before a year. I am attaching a picture of my face. Thanks.

### Response:Based on the description you provided, it seems like you are experiencing acne rosacea. Acne rosacea is a chronic skin condition characterized by redness, small red pimples, and inflammation. It commonly affects the face, particularly the cheeks, nose, forehead, and chin.

To help manage your acne rosacea, I would recommend the following steps:

1. Avoid triggers: Identify and avoid any triggers that may worsen your symptoms, such as spicy foods, alcohol, hot beverages, sunlight, stress, and certain skincare products.

2. Moisturize regularly: Use a gentle, fragrance-free moisturizer to keep your skin hydrated and help reduce inflammation.

3. Use topical treatments: Over-the-counter creams containing ingredients like metronidazole, azelaic acid, or sulfur can help reduce inflammation and kill bacteria. These are available in different strengths and should be used as directed.

4. Prescription medications: If over-the-counter treatments are not effective, your dermatologist may prescribe topical or oral antibiotics, isotretinoin (Accutane), or other medications specifically designed for treating acne rosacea

I would sleep with the contact lenses in my eyes and I have started wearing them since I was 13 years old. I would change them, but I would not take them off, and I would go days. My vision gets worse when I go to the eye doctor, but I have not had problems with infections. Recently I noticed that my left eye is red without pain or irritation, but red as the color of the pink eye. I do not know if it is the contact lenses which is causing the redness. Please help.

### Response:Based on the information you provided, it is important to note that wearing contact lenses continuously for an extended period of time can have negative effects on your eyes. Wearing contact lenses while sleeping is not recommended as it can lead to various complications such as corneal ulcers and infections.

The redness in your left eye without pain or irritation could be a sign of a condition called contact lens-induced conjunctivitis, also known as pink eye. This occurs when the wearing of contact lenses does not allow adequate oxygen to reach the surface of the eye, leading to inflammation and redness.

To properly diagnose and treat the redness in your eye, it is recommended that you schedule an appointment with an eye care professional. They will be able to assess the severity of the condition and provide appropriate treatment options, which may include removing the contact lenses and prescribing medicated eye drops or ointments.

It is crucial to discontinue the continuous wear of contact lenses and follow the advice of an eye care professional to prevent further complications and promote the health of your eyes.

input: Hello doctor,I am 26 years old. I have seen my period in the second month of last year and miss it up for a further two months. I have seen it again after three months and stopped at the end of that month. But anytime I have sexual intercourse, I will bleed and past lots of blood clots for at least three days and then stop, and I waited for four days. I was good until I had sex again the same bleeding occurs, and there was lots of blood clot. Please help.
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:
Hello doctor,I am 26 years old. I have seen my period in the second month of last year and miss it up for a further two months. I have seen it again after three months and stopped at the end of that month. But anytime I have sexual intercourse, I will bleed and past lots of blood clots for at least three days and then stop, and I waited for four days. I was good until I had sex again the same bleeding occurs, and there was lots of blood clot. Please help.

### Response:Based on the description you provided, it seems like you may be experiencing a condition called menorrhagia. This refers to heavy or prolonged menstrual bleeding.

There are several possible causes for menorrhagia, including hormonal imbalances, such as hypothyroidism or polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), uterine fibroids, pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), or certain medications. It is important to consult with a healthcare professional for a proper evaluation and diagnosis.

In the meantime, you can try some self-care measures to help manage your symptoms. These may include:

1. Using sanitary pads instead of tampons to absorb the flow.
2. Wearing looser-fitting, cotton underwear to reduce friction and irritation.

input: Hello doctor,I have spastic paraplegia. Everything I have tried has not worked. I was told to try a medication called L-Dopa. Will this medication help me?
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:
Hello doctor,I have spastic paraplegia. Everything I have tried has not worked. I was told to try a medication called L-Dopa. Will this medication help me?

### Response:As a doctor, I can provide you with information about L-Dopa and its potential benefits for individuals with spastic paraplegia.

L-Dopa, also known as levodopa, is a medication commonly used to treat Parkinson's disease. It is believed to work by increasing dopamine levels in the brain. Dopamine is a neurotransmitter that plays a role in movement control.

In individuals with spastic paraplegia, there is often a deficiency of dopamine in the affected areas of the brain. By increasing dopamine levels, L-Dopa may help improve muscle tone and reduce spasticity.

However, it is important to note that the effectiveness of L-Dopa can vary from person to person. Some individuals may experience significant improvements in their symptoms, while others may not respond as well.

Before starting any new medication, it is crucial to consult with your healthcare provider. They will evaluate your specific condition, consider any potential side effects or interactions with other medications, and determine if L-Dopa is an appropriate treatment option for you.

Please consult with your doctor to discuss whether L-Dopa is a suitable choice for your condition.

The symptoms mentioned, such as back pain on the right side, pain radiating down the leg, and numbness or tingling in the leg, are common signs of sciatica.

To confirm the diagnosis and determine the underlying cause of the sciatica, it is important for the patient to consult with a healthcare professional, such as a doctor or a physical therapist. Treatment options for sciatica may vary depending on the severity of the symptoms and the underlying cause. Non-invasive treatments commonly recommended include rest, physical therapy exercises, pain management techniques (such as heat or cold therapy), and medications to relieve pain and inflammation. In some cases, surgery may be considered if conservative treatments fail to provide relief.

It is important for the patient to follow the advice of their healthcare provider and to seek medical attention for a proper diagnosis and appropriate treatment plan.

input: Hello doctor,I have an odd thing happening in my left eye. I see a flash of light when I look right to left in the left side of my eye. It is a curve from top to bottom. It happens in daylight, nighttime, and even in the dark with my eyes closed. I move my pupil left to right and see a bright arc of light. I cannot make it stay there, it just flashes as I move my eye balls left to right. Any ideas?
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:
Hello doctor,I have an odd thing happening in my left eye. I see a flash of light when I look right to left in the left side of my eye. It is a curve from top to bottom. It happens in daylight, nighttime, and even in the dark with my eyes closed. I move my pupil left to right and see a bright arc of light. I cannot make it stay there, it just flashes as I move my eye balls left to right. Any ideas?

### Response:Based on the description you provided, it sounds like you are experiencing a phenomenon known as nystagmus. Nystagmus is an involuntary eye movement that can cause a perception of flashing lights.

There are several possible causes for nystagmus, including:

1. Ocular muscle imbalance: This can occur due to conditions such as strabismus (misaligned eyes), refractive errors, or certain neurological disorders.

2. Inner ear problems: Conditions affecting the inner ear, such as Ménière's disease or labyrinthitis, can lead to nystagmus.

3. Medications or substances: Certain medications, alcohol, or recreational drugs can cause nystagmus as a side effect.

4. Neurological disorders: Conditions like multiple sclerosis, stroke, or brain tumors can cause nystagmus.

To determine the exact cause of your symptoms, it would be best to consult with an ophthalmologist or a neurologist. They will perform a thorough examination, including tests to assess eye movements and possibly additional tests if needed.

Please note that this response does not constitute medical advice, and it is important to consult with a healthcare professional for an accurate diagnosis and appropriate treatment.

input: Hello doctor,Just two days ago I found out I was about 1-2 weeks pregnant. And it has been about 4 1/2 weeks since my last menstrual period. Unfortunately with labor day being this weekend I have been unable to see my regular OBGYN. But I did go to the ER to confirm the pregnancy 2 days ago. So my blood results came back with an HCG OF 248 and the doctor said I am right around 1-2 weeks.So, here is my question. I have been stressing out badly due to the fact I have been on Lorazepam 1 mg every night for anxiety and PD for the last 2 years as well as Percocet 10 mg as needed for back pain. I have been taking both of the medications during my pregnancy when I had no idea I was pregnant. Since finding out I have tried tapering on both medications. The Percocet is making me sweat and very agitated and when I tried to cut down on the Lorazepam I was shaking and almost hallucinating and delusion. I also tried not taking the Lorazepam at all and woke up crying, shaking and sweating. I want to be off both these medicines but I am worried more about the Lorazepam as it is a class D pregnancy drug. I have read about the terrible problems this causes for infants. I am so scared that I am considering abortion. I do not want to be a terrible mother before I even give birth. I have been having bad panic attacks over this and cannot seem to relax as the complications of these medicines are always on my mind. Any advice at all would be very much appreciated.

### Response:Based on the information provided, a pulse in the blood vessels can indicate normal blood flow and proper functioning of the heart. However, if the blood vessels have a pulse and there is a cardiac dysfunction, it suggests that the heart is not able to effectively pump blood throughout the body.

Cardiac dysfunction refers to any abnormality or malfunction in the structure or function of the heart. It can be caused by various factors such as coronary artery disease, heart valve problems, heart muscle diseases (such as cardiomyopathy), or congenital heart defects.

When a doctor detects a pulse in the blood vessels and also identifies cardiac dysfunction, it suggests that there may be an issue with the heart's ability to effectively pump blood. This can lead to symptoms such as fatigue, shortness of breath, chest pain, dizziness, or fluid retention.

It is important to consult with a cardiologist for further evaluation and management of cardiac dysfunction. They will perform additional tests, such as echocardiography or stress tests, to assess the structure and function of the heart, identify the underlying cause, and determine the appropriate treatment plan.

### Response:I'm sorry to hear about your chipped tooth. The recovery process can vary depending on the severity of the chip and the underlying tooth structure. Here are a few steps you can take to help recover your tooth:

1. Rinse your mouth: Gently rinse your mouth with warm saltwater to clean the area and reduce the risk of infection.

2. Apply a dental adhesive: Dental adhesives can help bond broken pieces of the tooth together and provide temporary protection. However, it's important to consult with a dentist before using any adhesive as they may need to assess the damage and provide specific instructions.

3. Avoid eating on the affected side: Until you can get professional dental care, it's best to avoid chewing or eating on the side of your mouth where the tooth is chipped. This will help prevent further damage and provide time for healing.

4. Schedule an appointment with a dentist: As soon as possible, schedule an appointment with a dentist who can assess the extent of the damage and determine the appropriate treatment options. They may recommend dental crowns, fillings, or other restorative procedures depending on the severity of the chip.

5. Practice good oral hygiene: Maintain good oral hygiene by brushing and flossing regularly

3. Hydroquinone: This medication can help lighten areas of hypopigmentation, although its use is generally limited due to potential side effects.
4. Tretino

input: Hello doctor,About a year ago, I started with tingling symptoms on the face, which was most consistent but also arms, legs, and torso those are more intermittent on both sides of the body. At time B12 was low started taking it after a couple of months symptoms better. Also, I had regular neuro examination and normal MRI of the head and cervical spine.After a few months, I stopped B12 levels up then a few months after the same symptoms again and B12 low again. The presence of tingling symptoms on the face, arms, legs, and torso, along with intermittent symptoms on both sides of the body, can be indicative of MS. These sensory disturbances are known as paresthesias and can occur in MS.

Additionally, the MRI findings of moderate to severe changes throughout the cervical spine, including narrowing of foraminal in all areas C3 to C7 and flattening of the ventral cord C3 through 6, are consistent with MS. These imaging findings are often seen in patients with MS.

However, it is important to note that these symptoms and MRI findings alone do not definitively diagnose MS. Further evaluation, including a thorough clinical examination and additional tests such as cerebrospinal fluid analysis and visual evoked potentials, may be necessary to confirm the diagnosis.

I recommend consulting with a neurologist who specializes in MS to discuss the patient's symptoms and undergo further diagnostic testing.

input: Hello doctor,My first baby is healthy and my blood group is A positive and my wife\s blood group is B negative. Now, my wife is again pregnant and has completed 26 weeks of pregnancy. She has developed antibodies and the latest ICT with titer test results show 1:64. Last week, we also did sonography and that did not have any impact on the baby.Now, the doctor suggests giving some steroids in this week which will help to develop the baby\s lungs faster to prevent any complication. Is it safe? If my baby\s blood group is also negative then are there any possibilities for antibodies to develop in my wife or does the baby\s blood group does not matter at all? Should I go ahead with NIPT to find the baby\s blood group?
raw_output:

### Instruction:

### Input:

She has developed antibodies and the latest ICT with titer test results show 1:64. Last week, we also did sonography and that did not have any impact on the baby.Now, the doctor suggests giving some steroids in this week which will help to develop the baby\s lungs faster to prevent any complication. Is it safe? If my baby\s blood group is also negative then are there any possibilities for antibodies to develop in my wife or does the baby\s blood group does not matter at all? Should I go ahead with NIPT to find the baby\s blood group?

### Response:Based on the information provided, it seems that your wife has developed antibodies during her current pregnancy. This can be a concern as it may increase the risk of complications such as preterm labor or fetal growth restriction.

The doctor's suggestion of giving steroids to help develop the baby's lungs faster is a common practice and generally considered safe. Steroids are known to reduce the risk of respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) in premature babies.

Regarding the baby's blood group, it does matter in certain situations. In this case, since your blood group is A positive and your wife's blood group is B negative, there is a possibility of blood group incompatibility. The Rh factor is an important consideration in these cases.

To determine the baby's blood group, you can consider doing a non-invasive prenatal testing (NIPT) test. This test analyzes fetal DNA present in the mother's blood and provides information about the baby's genetic material, including the Rh factor.

It is important to consult with your healthcare provider to discuss the specific situation and determine the best course of action for your wife's care. They will be able to provide personalized advice based on her medical history and the results of any previous tests.

input: Hello doctor,I am a 30 year old male, who is a competitive athlete. I do not have any structural or plumbing heart issues. I have been diagnosed with WPW accidentally, and I am waiting for an ablation in 17 days. I am mostly asymptomatic, and I never had any extremely rapid heart rates. My resting heart rate is actually in the 40\s. However, I do sometimes get palpitations and every once in awhile get a run of 5 to 7 in a row. The EP I saw in the hospital prescribed me Flecainide 50 mg, twice daily. I saw another EP, who was a much older guy, as a second opinion. He seems to think I do not need the Flecainide, and maybe not even the ablation. I have not had any palpitations since I began taking it a few days ago, but I want to make sure this drug is not putting me at risk for creating a dangerous rhythm. ### Response:As a medical expert, I can provide you with general information about abscesses. However, I am unable to diagnose or provide specific treatment recommendations without a physical examination. It is important to consult with a dentist or oral surgeon for an accurate diagnosis and appropriate treatment plan.

Abscesses are localized pockets of pus that form as a result of infection. They can occur in various parts of the body, including the teeth. In the case of a dental abscess, it typically develops at the root of a tooth due to an infection in the dental pulp or the space between the tooth and the gum.

The spread of an abscess throughout the body is not common unless there are underlying systemic conditions or complications such as a weakened immune system or a bacterial infection that has spread beyond the oral cavity. In most cases, localized treatment is sufficient to resolve the abscess and prevent further complications.

To effectively treat the abscess and prevent its spread, your dentist may recommend drainage of the abscess, antibiotics if necessary, and possibly root canal therapy or extraction of the affected tooth. It is important to follow their instructions and complete the prescribed treatment plan to ensure proper healing and prevention of further infection.

Please consult with a dental professional for an accurate diagnosis

instruction: If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.
input: Hello doctor,What is HMD (hereditary macular degeneration) and what is the maximum possible impact of this disease in future on a person? Can this disease make one blind?
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:
Hello doctor,What is HMD (hereditary macular degeneration) and what is the maximum possible impact of this disease in future on a person? Can this disease make one blind?

### Response:Hello,

HMD (hereditary macular degeneration) is a genetic disorder that affects the macula, which is responsible for central vision. It leads to progressive degeneration and loss of central vision, while peripheral vision remains intact.

The maximum possible impact of HMD on a person's future vision can vary depending on the specific genetic mutation and the individual's age of onset. In some cases, HMD may progress slowly over many years, while in others, it can progress more rapidly. In severe cases, HMD can cause significant visual impairment and even lead to legal blindness. However, it is important to note that not all individuals with HMD will experience the same level of vision loss.

While HMD cannot directly cause complete blindness, it can significantly impact a person's ability to see fine details and perform tasks requiring central vision, such as reading, recognizing faces, or driving.

It is essential for individuals with a family history of HMD or suspected symptoms to consult with an ophthalmologist for a comprehensive evaluation and appropriate management.

It is essential for individuals with a family history of HMD or suspected symptoms to consult with an ophthalmologist for a comprehensive evaluation and appropriate management.

If your insomnia persists or worsens despite stopping Prednisone, I would advise consulting with your doctor to further evaluate and explore potential underlying causes or contributing factors. instruction: If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.
input: Hello doctor,I am a 46-year-old male. A month ago, I had a heart stroke and underwent angio for blood clotting thrombus. My CBC report at that time shows a platelet count at 24 lakhs. I received CALR Exon 9 mutation analysis report today. It reads "CALR Exon 9 mutation is detected by PCR amplification of Exon 9 of CALR, followed by sequencing of coding and junctional region of the Exon. The sequence is compared with the reference sequence NM-004343 for the analysis of mutations." Hematologist prescribed me Anagrelide 0.5 mg. Do I have to worry? Can it be cured by medication?
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:
Hello doctor,I am a 46-year-old male. A month ago, I had a heart stroke and underwent angio for blood clotting thrombus. My CBC report at that time shows a platelet count at 24 lakhs. I received CALR Exon 9 mutation analysis report today. It reads "CALR Exon 9 mutation is detected by PCR amplification of Exon 9 of CALR, followed by sequencing of coding and junctional region of the Exon. The sequence is compared with the reference sequence NM-004343 for the analysis of mutations." Hematologist prescribed me Anagrelide 0.5 mg. Do I have to worry? Can it be cured by medication?

### Response:Based on the information provided, it seems like you have been diagnosed with a condition called essential thrombocythemia (ET), which is characterized by an increased platelet count. The CALR Exon 9 mutation analysis report indicates the presence of a mutation in the CALR gene, which is commonly associated with ET.

The prescribed medication, Anagrelide, is commonly used to manage ET by reducing the production of platelets. It works by inhibiting the action of certain enzymes involved in platelet production.

While medication can help manage the symptoms and reduce the risk of complications associated with ET, it does not cure the condition. ET is a chronic disorder that requires long-term monitoring and treatment. Regular follow-up appointments with your hematologist will be necessary to assess your condition and adjust the treatment plan if needed.

It is important to follow your hematologist's instructions and take the prescribed medication as directed. If you have any concerns or questions about your treatment, I recommend discussing them with your healthcare provider.

instruction: If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.
input: Hello doctor,Suddenly, my right eye got smaller than my left eye for a few seconds (15 seconds) and then it came back to normal. It has happened a few times now. Why is this?
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:
Hello doctor,Suddenly, my right eye got smaller than my left eye for a few seconds (15 seconds) and then it came back to normal. It has happened a few times now. Why is this?

### Response:Based on the description provided, it is possible that you are experiencing a condition called heterotropia. Heterotropia refers to a deviation of the eyes from the normal midline position. It can be temporary or intermittent and may occur in one or both eyes.

The sudden decrease in size of your right eye followed by it returning to normal suggests that there may be a reflex mechanism involved. This reflex is known as the accommodation reflex or the vergence-accommodation reflex.

During this reflex, when the eyes are not properly aligned, the ciliary muscle in the eye contracts to change the shape of the lens, allowing for better focus and alignment of the eyes. This contraction of the ciliary muscle temporarily reduces the size of the eye, bringing it back into alignment.

It is important to note that heterotropia can have various causes, including refractive errors, strabismus (misaligned eyes), or other underlying conditions. Therefore, it is recommended to consult with an ophthalmologist for a thorough evaluation and diagnosis. They will be able to provide a more accurate diagnosis and appropriate treatment if necessary.

instruction: If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.
input: Hello doctor,I am a 31-year-old male with a history of closed globe injury in the right eye 10 years ago. At that time, my vision in the right eye was hand movements only and I was diagnosed with a macular injury. Three months later, my vision slowly improved to 6/36. However, my right eye started to deviate (exotropia) and I started experiencing diplopia. My main problem is diplopia. I have used prisms, but of no use. When I try to focus on an image, I have severe diplopia. The diplopia disappears when I try to correct the squint. At present, I am doing higher studies and the diplopia is really bothering me. Will doing a squint surgery be of any use? Is there anything that I can try?
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:

However, my right eye started to deviate (exotropia) and I started experiencing diplopia. My main problem is diplopia. I have used prisms, but of no use. When I try to focus on an image, I have severe diplopia. The diplopia disappears when I try to correct the squint. At present, I am doing higher studies and the diplopia is really bothering me. Will doing a squint surgery be of any use? Is there anything that I can try?

### Response:Based on the information provided, it seems that you are experiencing diplopia due to a misalignment of the eyes, known as exotropia. The history of a closed globe injury and the improvement in vision over time suggest that there may be damage to the visual pathway or the muscles controlling eye movement.

Squint surgery, also known as strabismus surgery, is a procedure performed to correct the alignment of the eyes and improve binocular vision. It involves repositioning or resecting the muscles that control eye movement. In your case, since diplopia persists despite using prisms, squint surgery may not be effective in alleviating your symptoms.

There are alternative treatment options that can be considered for managing diplopia in cases where surgery is not suitable or has not provided adequate relief. These include:

1. Orthoptic exercises: These exercises aim to improve eye coordination and alignment. They may involve following moving targets with the eyes, performing visual acuity tasks, or focusing on specific targets while moving the eyes in certain patterns.

2. Vision therapy: This involves a structured program of eye exercises, targeted at improving visual processing and eye coordination. It may include activities such as eye movements, convergence exercises, and near vision tasks.

3. Pr

input: Hello doctor,I have an anal fissure, internal hemorrhoid, SRUS, and constipation. One year ago, I was suffering from a hard stool that was difficult to pass. However, my pain did not subside. I used to evacuate the stools using my fingers. That eliminated the stools, but there was so much mucus released and extreme pain after motion. Two months ago, I went to a GP who gave me some antibiotics and painkillers for five days. During this time, I was always sleepy. I took leave from work and was always tired and fatigued. Earlier this month, I went to another GI specialist who did a sigmoidoscopy and said that it is SRUS. He said that I should not finger evacuate the stools and gave me liquid paraffin and LoX cream. Now, my current situation is that it has been three days and I am very constipated and fatigued. The pain has subsided a little. However, I am not passing stools as I used to before. After I drink water or eat something, I get a vomiting sensation. I get anxiety and panic attacks as I am scared about my condition and do not know which doctor I should consult and what I should do. ### Response:Based on the information provided, it is important to consider the risk of pregnancy after unprotected sex and the use of emergency contraception.

The I-pill, also known as the morning-after pill, works by preventing ovulation and thickening the cervical mucus to block sperm from reaching the egg. It is most effective when taken within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse.

However, if you had sex again within three days after taking the I-pill, there is a possibility that you may still be at risk of pregnancy. The effectiveness of the I-pill decreases with each subsequent intercourse.

To determine the best course of action, it is recommended to consult with a healthcare professional or visit a sexual health clinic. They will be able to provide you with personalized advice based on your specific situation and guide you through any necessary steps.

input: Hello doctor,I would like to know if my hypothyroidism can be cured without taking the synthetic hormones, through Ayurveda only. In the allopathic approach, the hormone needs to be taken for the rest of one\s life and I am a bit scared of it. It is possible I may also be diabetic and will need to treat this as well. Can these conditions be successfully dealt with through ayurvedic treatments alone?
raw_output:

### Input:

In the allopathic approach, the hormone needs to be taken for the rest of one\s life and I am a bit scared of it. It is possible I may also be diabetic and will need to treat this as well. Can these conditions be successfully dealt with through ayurvedic treatments alone?

### Response:As a doctor, I can provide information about hypothyroidism and its treatment options. Hypothyroidism is a condition where the thyroid gland does not produce enough thyroid hormone, leading to various symptoms such as fatigue, weight gain, and sensitivity to cold.

In terms of treatment, hypothyroidism is usually managed with synthetic thyroid hormone medication, such as levothyroxine, which is taken daily for life. This medication helps to replace the deficient hormone and restore normal thyroid function.

While alternative treatments like Ayurveda can be considered alongside conventional medicine, it is important to note that there is no known cure for hypothyroidism without medication. The goal of treatment is to manage symptoms and restore hormone levels to normal.

If you suspect you may have diabetes in addition to hypothyroidism, it is crucial to consult with both an endocrinologist (for thyroid issues) and an internist or diabetologist (for diabetes). They will be able to evaluate your specific situation and provide appropriate treatment plans.

It is always recommended to discuss your concerns and treatment options with your healthcare provider, as they will be able to provide personalized advice based on your individual health needs.

input: Hello doctor,I have an important query about the contraceptive pill. On the 2nd, my girlfriend started her period. It is now the 16th. So, I believe she is in her ovulation phase. Since her period stopped, she has begun, for the very first time, taking the combined contraceptive pill consistently at 8 AM every morning. She took the pill yesterday morning. Last night, on the 15th of March, we had unprotected sex (we thought one night without condoms would be fine). However, this morning she was in a rush and forgot to take her pill for today. It is 2:16 PM now and I have a few urgent questions:Should she take the morning after pill?How effective will the morning after pill be in protecting from pregnancy?How much will the pills previously taken lower the risk of pregnancy?Given her current stage of ovulation, what is the risk of her becoming pregnant? The period of time between the missed pill at 8 AM this morning and the time that she will take the morning-after pill (around 4 PM)?Do you recommend taking today's pill today if she is also taking the morning after pill today?Is there anything else we can do now to minimize the risk?Should we be worried?Thank you.
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:
Hello doctor,I have an important query about the contraceptive pill. On the 2nd, my girlfriend started her period. It is now the 16th. So, I believe she is in her ovulation phase. Since her period stopped, she has begun, for the very first time, taking the combined contraceptive pill consistently at 8 AM every morning. She took the pill yesterday morning. Last night, on the 15th of March, we had unprotected sex (we thought one night without condoms would be fine). However, this morning she was in a rush and forgot to take her pill for today. It is 2:16 PM now and I have a few urgent questions:Should she take the morning after pill?How effective will the morning after pill be in protecting from pregnancy?How much will the pills previously taken lower the risk of pregnancy?Given her current stage of ovulation, what is the risk of her becoming pregnant? The period of time between the missed pill at 8 AM this morning and the time that she will take the morning-after pill (around 4 PM)?Do you recommend taking today's pill today if she is also taking the morning after pill today?Is there anything else we can do now to minimize the risk?Should we be worried?Thank you.

### Response:Based on the information provided, it is important to consider the risk of pregnancy given the missed combined contraceptive pill.

1. Should she take the morning after pill?
Yes, she should take the morning after pill as soon as possible. The morning after pill is most effective when taken within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse.

2. How effective will the morning after pill be in protecting from pregnancy?
The morning after pill is highly effective in preventing pregnancy when taken within the recommended time frame. It can significantly reduce the risk of pregnancy by up to 95%.

3. How much will the pills previously taken lower the risk of pregnancy?
The combined contraceptive pill, if taken consistently and correctly, significantly reduces the risk of pregnancy. However, since the missed pill occurred recently, the effectiveness may be reduced.

4. Given her current stage of ovulation, what is the risk of her becoming pregnant?
The risk of pregnancy without the protection of the combined contraceptive pill is higher during the fertile phase of the menstrual cycle, which typically occurs around the time of ovulation. Since her period stopped and she started taking the pill consistently, the risk of pregnancy may be lower. However, without the protection of the missed pill, the risk of pregnancy is higher.

I took pictures of it and have it in a baggie and I contacted my doctor\s service but have gotten no response. I have no medical insurance. So, I faced the mirror and pulled the skin open around my belly button and a small white worm came out. I took pictures of it and have it in a baggie and I contacted my doctor\s service but have gotten no response. I have no medical insurance. ### Response:Based on the patient's description, it is possible that they are experiencing a parasitic infection. The presence of a small white worm coming out of the belly button suggests a condition called "hookworm."

Hookworm is a type of parasitic infection caused by the hookworm larvae. It is usually transmitted through contact with contaminated soil or infected animals. The larvae penetrate the skin and migrate to the abdominal cavity, where they mature into adult worms.

To confirm the diagnosis and determine the appropriate treatment, it is important for the patient to seek medical attention from a healthcare professional. The doctor will need to perform a physical examination and possibly conduct additional tests, such as blood tests or stool analysis, to confirm the presence of hookworm.

Treatment for hookworm typically involves the use of medications called anthelmintics, which are specifically designed to kill the worms. It is important to follow the prescribed treatment plan provided by the healthcare professional.

In the meantime, it is advisable for the patient to avoid contact with contaminated soil or environments where hookworm may be present. They should also practice good hygiene, wash their hands regularly, and keep the infected area clean and covered to prevent further contamination.

The question is could it be harmful to make another cycle or should I stop? Now, that I have stopped should I do a PCT? My wish would be to increase the penis dimensions without damaging my HPTA axis.

### Response:Based on the information provided, it seems like you are concerned about the potential harmful effects of making another cycle of DHT gel and whether or not you should do a PCT (Post Cycle Therapy).

Firstly, it is important to note that the use of DHT gel for the purpose of penis enlargement is not recommended. DHT gel is typically used for medical conditions such as male pattern baldness or prostate enlargement. It is not approved for use in penis enlargement.

Secondly, it is crucial to consider the potential risks and side effects associated with long-term use of high-dose DHT. Prolonged use of DHT can suppress natural testosterone production, leading to decreased testosterone levels and potentially causing hormonal imbalances. This can have various negative effects on your body and overall health.

Additionally, it is essential to understand that DHT gel contains a high concentration of DHT, which is a potent androgen hormone. Excessive use of DHT gel over an extended period of time can disrupt the normal functioning of the HPTA (Hypothalamic-Pituitary-Testicular-Axis), which regulates hormone production in the body. Disruption of the HPTA axis can lead to decreased testosterone production and potentially permanent damage.

If your symptoms persist or worsen, it would be advisable to consult with an eye care professional for a comprehensive evaluation and personalized treatment plan.

input: Hi doctor,My wife is suffering from peripartum cardiomyopathy for the past six months. She is taking beta blockers and diuretic medicine for the past four months. Her heart EF is 38 % with flat T in ECG reports. Her heart function is normal. How many days does it take to get cured?
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:
Hi doctor,My wife is suffering from peripartum cardiomyopathy for the past six months. She is taking beta blockers and diuretic medicine for the past four months. Her heart EF is 38 % with flat T in ECG reports. Her heart function is normal. How many days does it take to get cured?

### Response:I'm sorry to hear about your wife's condition. Peripartum cardiomyopathy is a serious heart condition that can occur during pregnancy or within the first few months after delivery. The treatment for this condition typically involves medications such as beta blockers and diuretics to improve heart function and manage symptoms.

The ejection fraction (EF) of 38% indicates that her heart is pumping out only 38% of the blood with each contraction, which is below the normal range. The flat T in the ECG reports suggests that her heart's electrical conduction system may also be affected.

The recovery time for peripartum cardiomyopathy can vary from person to person. In general, it may take several months to a year for the heart to fully recover and return to normal function. However, it's important to note that complete recovery is not guaranteed, and some women may experience ongoing heart problems.

It would be best for your wife to follow up regularly with her healthcare provider to monitor her progress and adjust her treatment plan as needed. Additionally, lifestyle modifications such as maintaining a healthy diet, regular exercise, and stress management can also contribute to her overall well-being and heart health.

### Response:Hello,

I'm sorry to hear about your situation. As a medical expert, I can provide some information on the NIPT test.

The Non-Invasive Prenatal Test (NIPT) is a screening test that analyzes fetal DNA present in the mother's blood. It is typically recommended for women who have a higher risk of having a baby with a chromosomal abnormality, such as advanced maternal age or a family history of genetic disorders.

In your case, since the level 1 ultrasound and the double marker test are normal, it suggests that there is a lower risk of chromosomal abnormalities. However, the decision to perform the NIPT test ultimately lies with your doctor. They will consider various factors, including your wife's age and any additional risk factors, to determine if the NIPT test is necessary.

It's important to follow your doctor's advice and discuss any concerns or questions you may have with them directly. They will be able to provide you with more specific information regarding the NIPT test and its relevance in your situation.

input: Hello doctor,I have minor beta thalassemia which I got from my mother, but unlike her (asymptomatic), I have anemia symptoms like paleness, shortness of breath after the least effort, feeling tired all the time, broken nails and I want to know if it could be due to lack of iron? Could people with minor beta thalassemia also get iron deficiency anemia? Knowing that I get heavy cycles and my diet is very poor.
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:
Hello doctor,I have minor beta thalassemia which I got from my mother, but unlike her (asymptomatic), I have anemia symptoms like paleness, shortness of breath after the least effort, feeling tired all the time, broken nails and I want to know if it could be due to lack of iron? Could people with minor beta thalassemia also get iron deficiency anemia? Knowing that I get heavy cycles and my diet is very poor.

### Response:Based on the symptoms you described, it is possible that your anemia could be due to iron deficiency. People with minor beta thalassemia can indeed develop iron deficiency anemia.

Iron is essential for the production of red blood cells, which carry oxygen throughout the body. Beta thalassemia is a genetic disorder that affects the production of hemoglobin, the protein responsible for carrying oxygen in red blood cells. In individuals with beta thalassemia, there may be a decreased ability to produce enough healthy red blood cells, leading to anemia.

Iron deficiency anemia occurs when there is a lack of iron in the body, which is necessary for the production of hemoglobin. This can happen if the diet lacks iron-rich foods or if there is excessive iron loss through menstruation or other sources.

To confirm whether your anemia is due to iron deficiency, it would be best to undergo further medical evaluation, including blood tests to assess your iron levels and a complete blood count (CBC) to evaluate the number and quality of your red blood cells.

I recommend consulting with a healthcare professional who can provide a proper diagnosis and develop an appropriate treatment plan for you.

### Response:Hello,

Based on the information you provided, it seems like you have a urinary tract infection (UTI) caused by Enterococcus faecalis. This type of bacteria is commonly associated with catheter-related infections and can cause UTIs in individuals with indwelling urinary catheters.

Since you do not have any symptoms of UTI or abscess, it is possible that the infection has been localized to the surgical site and is not spreading throughout your urinary system. However, it is important to treat the infection to prevent any potential complications.

In this case, a course of antibiotics is usually recommended to treat the UTI caused by Enterococcus faecalis. The choice of antibiotics will depend on various factors such as your medical history and local resistance patterns. I would recommend consulting with your surgeon or primary care physician to determine the most appropriate antibiotic treatment for your specific situation.

As for the cystocele repair not being successful and the bladder being at the mouth of the vagina, it is possible that this is due to a condition called vesicovaginal fistula. This occurs when there is an abnormal connection between the bladder and the vagina, allowing urine to leak into the vaginal cavity.

I

input: Hi doctor,I have been with the same partner for 8 years now. During these all 8 years I have had several UTIs with some leading to severe kidney infections. Last week after almost two years of not having a UTI I felt the horrible symptoms again. When going to the doctors UTI urine test came back positive. The doctor prescribed me seven days Nitrofurantoin antibiotics which cleared the pain and seemed gone entirely. Unfortunately two days later, the symptoms came back (please note that I had sex with my partner the day before) with burning sensation when urinating and painful when standing with the need to go toilet every 2 to 3 minutes. I went back to the clinic the same day to get it checked and take more antibiotics.But to my surprise, the urine test came back clear for UTI, and my symptoms disappeared. Then the doctor advised me to get tested for Chlamydia as the symptoms can sometimes be mistaken to be UTI. I have been diagnosed with Chlamydia at the beginning of this same relationship and was treated for it. My partner was also tested, but his results came back negative. Is it possible that the treatment that I had for Chlamydia 8 years ago did not clear it entirely and this lead to several UTIs and kidney infections? And also, would the antibiotics for UTI clear Chlamydia? Thank you in advance for your help.

Then the doctor advised me to get tested for Chlamydia as the symptoms can sometimes be mistaken to be UTI. I have been diagnosed with Chlamydia at the beginning of this same relationship and was treated for it. My partner was also tested, but his results came back negative. Is it possible that the treatment that I had for Chlamydia 8 years ago did not clear it entirely and this lead to several UTIs and kidney infections? And also, would the antibiotics for UTI clear Chlamydia? Thank you in advance for your help.

### Response:Based on the information provided, it is possible that the treatment for Chlamydia 8 years ago did not completely clear the infection. This could explain why you have been experiencing recurrent UTIs and kidney infections.

Regarding the antibiotics for UTI, they can indeed clear Chlamydia. The antibiotics commonly used to treat UTIs, such as Nitrofurantoin, are effective against both Chlamydia and other bacterial pathogens commonly associated with UTIs. Therefore, it is possible that the initial treatment for Chlamydia did not completely eradicate the infection, leading to ongoing UTI symptoms.

It is important to follow up with your healthcare provider to discuss these findings and determine the appropriate course of action. They may recommend further testing, such as a nucleic acid amplification test (NAAT) or a culture, to confirm the presence of Chlamydia and guide treatment decisions.

### Response:As a doctor, I can provide some information on the treatment options for uterine fibroids. Hysterectomy is a surgical procedure that involves removing the entire uterus, and it is typically recommended for symptomatic fibroids that are causing significant symptoms. However, if you are in your perimenopausal phase, there are alternative treatment options that may be considered before proceeding with a hysterectomy.

One such option is medication. Fibroids can sometimes shrink with the use of certain medications. The most commonly prescribed medication for fibroids is called GnRH agonists, such as leuprolide acetate or goserelin. These medications work by suppressing the hormones that stimulate the growth of fibroids. By reducing the levels of these hormones, the fibroids may gradually shrink over time.

Another medication that has been used to treat fibroids is the oral contraceptive pill (OCP). The combination OCPs containing estrogen and progestin have been shown to reduce the size of fibroids in some women. However, it is important to note that not all women respond to this treatment, and the benefits may vary.

It is essential to discuss these treatment options with your gynecologist, as they will be able to evaluate your specific case and

input: Hello doctor,My daughter is 18 months of age. She was born at 38 weeks due to placenta failure and oxygen issues. She was 5 lbs 10 ounces at birth and was healthy (did not have to stay in the NICU). She hit all of her milestones in terms of rolling over, crawling and walking (walked at 14.5 months), but is a toe walker. Her left leg (to us) is weaker than her right and her left leg does not bend as much as her right leg. She began to speak around 10 months of age then her speech left. We came to find out she had chronic fluid and a month back she had tubes placed. I am hearing more vowel and consonants now but no true words yet. She makes fine eye contact. Her non-verbal communication is good. She responds to her name but not always. She is beginning to learn more of what we are saying, she plays with some toys, is not terribly social. We are thinking that she may be on the autism spectrum and we have an evaluation soon to determine that. But my question is, could this be cerebral palsy?
