instruction: If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.
input: Hello doctor,How accurate in your opinion is the Lelli ACL (Lever test)? I am almost three months post-op of having my ACL reconstructed along with a few lesions addressed during the surgery. I am concerned I have ruptured my ACL again after feeling a short sharp pain when turning in the sand on vacation. It has been three days since the incident and the knee now feels a lot looser and I have some pain in different areas. I have tried the Lachman test with no noticeable shifting, and the Lelli test was positive with good leverage hopefully assisted by my intact ACL. I will have to see my surgeon and physio soon but I am just wondering how accurate the Lelli test is. There seems to be no difference when comparing the test in both knees.
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:
Hello doctor,How accurate in your opinion is the Lelli ACL (Lever test)? I am almost three months post-op of having my ACL reconstructed along with a few lesions addressed during the surgery. I am concerned I have ruptured my ACL again after feeling a short sharp pain when turning in the sand on vacation. It has been three days since the incident and the knee now feels a lot looser and I have some pain in different areas. I have tried the Lachman test with no noticeable shifting, and the Lelli test was positive with good leverage hopefully assisted by my intact ACL. I will have to see my surgeon and physio soon but I am just wondering how accurate the Lelli test is. There seems to be no difference when comparing the test in both knees.

### Response:The Lelli test is a clinical test used to assess the integrity of the ACL. It involves applying a force to the knee while it is bent at 30 degrees and examining for any give or instability.

In your case, the positive Lelli test with good leverage suggests that there may be a partial tear or re-injury to your ACL. However, it is important to note that the Lelli test alone cannot definitively diagnose a complete ACL rupture.

To confirm the diagnosis, additional tests such as the Lachman test and/or an MRI may be necessary. The Lachman test assesses the stability of the knee by measuring the amount of forward movement of the tibia (shinbone) relative to the femur (thighbone) during knee extension.

It is also worth mentioning that the accuracy of the Lelli test may vary depending on the individual and the skill of the healthcare provider performing the test. Therefore, it is recommended to consult with your surgeon and physiotherapist for a comprehensive evaluation and further management.
response:
The Lelli test is a clinical test used to assess the integrity of the ACL. It involves applying a force to the knee while it is bent at 30 degrees and examining for any give or instability.

In your case, the positive Lelli test with good leverage suggests that there may be a partial tear or re-injury to your ACL. However, it is important to note that the Lelli test alone cannot definitively diagnose a complete ACL rupture.

To confirm the diagnosis, additional tests such as the Lachman test and/or an MRI may be necessary. The Lachman test assesses the stability of the knee by measuring the amount of forward movement of the tibia (shinbone) relative to the femur (thighbone) during knee extension.

It is also worth mentioning that the accuracy of the Lelli test may vary depending on the individual and the skill of the healthcare provider performing the test. Therefore, it is recommended to consult with your surgeon and physiotherapist for a comprehensive evaluation and further management.

input: Hi doctor,I am a student, and I stay in a highly polluted area. I got shifted here five months ago. Early in the morning as soon as I wake up for five to ten minutes, my eyes start paining and irritating. Few times it also turns red. Due to this I could not wake up on time and also feel uncomfortable. When I study I feel some dryness in my eyes. Please help me out with some suggestion.

Early in the morning as soon as I wake up for five to ten minutes, my eyes start paining and irritating. Few times it also turns red. Due to this I could not wake up on time and also feel uncomfortable. When I study I feel some dryness in my eyes. Please help me out with some suggestion.

### Response:Based on the symptoms you described, it seems like you are experiencing eye irritation and discomfort due to the high levels of pollution in your area. Here are some suggestions to help alleviate these symptoms:

1. Avoid rubbing your eyes: Rubbing your eyes can further irritate them and worsen the symptoms.

2. Use lubricating eye drops: Applying over-the-counter lubricating eye drops can provide relief by reducing dryness and soothing the eyes. Look for eye drops that contain artificial tears or hyaluronic acid.

3. Wear sunglasses: Wearing sunglasses with UV protection can help shield your eyes from the pollutants in the air and reduce irritation.

4. Practice good hygiene: Make sure to wash your hands regularly, especially before touching your eyes, as this can help prevent the spread of any potential infections.

5. Improve indoor air quality: Consider using an air purifier or maintaining good ventilation in your living space to reduce exposure to pollutants indoors.

6. Protect your eyes during outdoor activities: When you go outside, wear a mask or face covering to protect your eyes from the pollutants in the air.

7. Stay hydrated

raw_output:

### Instruction:

### Input:
Hello doctor,Why do I have dry skin around my mouth and how can I treat it?

### Response:Hello! Dry skin around the mouth can be caused by several factors. One common cause is a condition called xerostomia, which is characterized by reduced saliva production. This can occur due to various reasons such as certain medications, salivary gland problems, or even aging. Other potential causes include inadequate hydration, excessive mouth breathing, or underlying medical conditions like hypothyroidism or Sjögren's syndrome.

To treat dry skin around the mouth, you can try the following:

1. Stay hydrated: Drink plenty of water throughout the day to maintain adequate hydration.
2. Moisturize regularly: Use a gentle, fragrance-free moisturizer specifically designed for the lips and mouth area. Apply it daily to keep the skin soft and supple.
3. Avoid excessive mouth breathing: If you notice that you frequently breathe through your mouth, try to improve your overall breathing habits by breathing through your nose more.
4. Use lip balms: Apply lip balms that contain ingredients like shea butter, cocoa butter, or beeswax to moisturize and protect your lips.
5. Avoid irritants: Be cautious of using harsh chemicals or alcohol-based mouthwashes,

Look for a cleanser that contains ingredients like glycerin or hyaluronic acid to hydrate your skin. As for your body, you can follow the same routine as for your face. Use a gentle cleanser and moisturizer specifically designed for your skin type. Remember to avoid harsh soaps and scrubbing, as this can further irritate the skin.

It's important to note that if your acne persists or worsens, it's advisable to consult with a dermatologist who can provide a personalized treatment plan based on your specific needs.

### Response:The normal range of cortisol in a 24-hour collected urine probe is typically between 50-250 \xb5g/24 hours. Having low cortisol levels in a 24-hour collected urine probe can be a clinical matter, especially if it is significantly below the normal range. In your case, with three urine testings showing cortisol levels between 10-12 \xb5g/24 hours, it suggests possible adrenal insufficiency or dysfunction.

Adrenal insufficiency can be caused by various factors, including stress (such as PTSD), chronic illness, medications, or other underlying medical conditions. It can lead to symptoms like fatigue, weakness, weight loss, low blood pressure, and difficulty tolerating stress.

Considering your symptoms and the low cortisol levels in your urine tests, it would be advisable to consult with a healthcare professional, preferably a specialist in endocrinology or primary care physician experienced in managing adrenal disorders. They can further evaluate your symptoms, perform additional tests if necessary, and provide appropriate treatment options based on the underlying cause of your cortisol deficiency.

### Response:Based on the description provided, it seems that your one-year-old baby is experiencing a condition called baby bottle tooth decay or early childhood caries. This occurs when the front teeth are exposed to frequent exposure to sugary liquids such as milk, formula, or juice, which can lead to tooth decay.

To address this issue, I would recommend the following steps:

1. Limit sugary drinks: Avoid giving your baby sugary drinks, including milk, formula, and juice, especially during naps and bedtime. Instead, offer water or breast milk.

2. Brush teeth regularly: Start brushing your baby's teeth twice a day using a soft-bristled toothbrush and fluoride toothpaste. Make sure to clean all surfaces of the teeth, including the front ones.

3. Use fluoride products: Consider using fluoride toothpaste or gel, especially for bedtime brushing. Fluoride helps to strengthen the teeth and prevent decay.

4. Schedule regular dental visits: Take your baby for regular dental check-ups and cleanings to monitor the health of her teeth and tooth development.

5. Diet modifications: Encourage healthy eating habits by offering a variety of nutritious foods and limiting sugary snacks.

However, it is always recommended to consult with a healthcare professional for a thorough evaluation and to discuss any concerns you may have.

It is important to remember that self-tanning creams can still contain harmful ingredients even if they are not actively used. It may take several years for any potential cancer-causing effects to manifest. Regular skin checks and early detection are crucial in detecting any abnormalities.

I would strongly encourage you to schedule an appointment with a dermatologist who can assess your individual situation and provide personalized advice based on your medical history and current health status.

input: Hi doctor,I had LASIK done for my eyes two months back. My vision is all right but, I feel a burning sensation at the corners of the eyes (corners from where tear comes). After 20 days of LASIK, (back then) whenever I put any eye drops my eyes started burning. Due to the burning sensation, my eyes started watering. I had consulted many doctors, and they prescribed eye drops like Systane Ultra, L-Pred, and Eubri. But no eye drops help me. I do not know what to do. Sometimes I also get redness in the eyes. Is it dryness or something else?

Is it dryness or something else?

### Response:Based on the description you provided, it seems like you are experiencing symptoms of dry eye after LASIK surgery. Dry eye can occur as a result of the surgery, as the corneal flap created during LASIK may temporarily affect the tear production glands.

The burning sensation at the corners of your eyes and the watering eyes you mentioned could be indicative of dry eye. The use of eye drops like Systane Ultra, L-Pred, and Eubri may provide temporary relief but do not address the underlying cause.

To manage dry eye after LASIK, I would recommend the following steps:

1. Use artificial tears: Apply lubricating eye drops such as Systane Ultra or other over-the-counter artificial tears regularly throughout the day to keep your eyes moist.

2. Avoid dry environments: Minimize exposure to dry environments such as air conditioning or heating systems, as they can worsen dryness.

3. Protect your eyes from wind and sun: Wear sunglasses outdoors to protect your eyes from wind and UV rays, which can further dry out your eyes.

4. Avoid smoking and alcohol: Smoking and excessive alcohol consumption can contribute to dry eye symptoms.

5. Use a humidifier: Keeping

### Response:Based on the patient's description and lab results, it appears that they have low testosterone levels. The normal range for testosterone levels in adult males is typically between 300-1000 ng/dL. In this case, the patient's testosterone level of 485 ng/dL falls within the low range, indicating possible hypogonadism or low testosterone.

The symptoms mentioned, such as anxiety, fatigue, gynecomastia (enlargement of breast tissue in men), low libido, no morning hardness, and muscle loss, are commonly associated with low testosterone levels.

However, it is important to note that a single lab result alone does not provide a definitive diagnosis. Additional evaluation and consultation with a healthcare professional specializing in endocrinology or urology would be necessary to confirm the diagnosis and determine appropriate treatment options.

### Response:As a doctor, I can provide you with some suggestions to help alleviate your gag reflex. However, it is important to consult with your dentist or orthodontist before attempting any of these methods. Here are a few strategies that may be helpful:

1. Desensitizing toothpaste: Your dentist may recommend using a desensitizing toothpaste before your dental appointment. These toothpastes contain ingredients that help reduce sensitivity over time.

2. Topical anesthetics: Your dentist may apply a topical anesthetic gel before the procedure to numb the area and reduce gagging.

3. Distraction techniques: You can try focusing on something else during the procedure to distract your mind from the sensation of gagging. Listening to music, watching a video, or engaging in conversation with the dentist or assistant can help divert your attention.

4. Deep breathing and relaxation: Practicing deep breathing exercises and relaxation techniques before the appointment can help calm your mind and body, potentially reducing gag reflex.

5. Medication: In some cases, your dentist may prescribe medication, such as anti-anxiety medications, to help manage your gag reflex.

Remember, it is essential to communicate openly with your dentist

Additionally, the high alkaline phosphatase level can be indicative of liver dysfunction, which can occur in this condition.

I would recommend consulting with the endocrinologist who referred your son for further evaluation and management. They will be able to provide a definitive diagnosis and develop an appropriate treatment plan based on your son's specific symptoms and test results.

input: Hello doctor,I noticed a small triangular bald spot in my beard three weeks ago. It was likely alopecia areata. Saw my dermatologist last week, she said it was likely folliculitis. I am not sure how long they may have been there as they were somewhat masked by a longer pubic hair. So, now I have what I believe to be three spots, two below abdomen and one on beard. ### Response:Based on the information provided, the presence of white and brown long particles in your stool can indicate a potential issue with your pregnancy. This is known as meconium-stained stool and can be a sign of meconium aspiration syndrome.

Meconium aspiration syndrome occurs when the baby inhales or swallows meconium (the baby's first stool) during vaginal delivery or cesarean section. The meconium can then get into the amniotic fluid and cause respiratory problems for the baby.

It is important to seek medical attention promptly if you notice this change in your stool. Your healthcare provider will need to assess the situation and determine the best course of action. They may recommend further tests such as amniocentesis or ultrasound to evaluate the baby's well-being and provide appropriate interventions if necessary.

Please contact your healthcare provider immediately to discuss your concerns and schedule an appointment for further evaluation.

But, I am hesitant and kind of rejecting to do so.After a month, the nail is not loose anymore, but the nail seems to be growing outwards, and between the nail and the nail bed, there is a gap (kind of like a hollow gap inside). ### Response:Based on the patient's description and the provided readings, there are several concerning findings.

1. Abnormal t-wave: The t-wave is responsible for representing ventricular repolarization. An abnormal t-wave can be indicative of various cardiac conditions, including myocardial ischemia (lack of blood flow to the heart muscle).

2. High QRS voltage: A high QRS voltage suggests an abnormal electrical conduction pathway in the heart. It can be seen in conditions such as ventricular tachycardia or ventricular fibrillation.

3. Abnormal Qtc: Qtc stands for the duration of the QRS complex on the ECG tracing. An abnormal Qtc can indicate underlying heart disease or arrhythmias.

4. Pulse 60: A resting heart rate of 60 beats per minute is considered bradycardia, which may be due to various causes including autonomic nervous system dysfunction, medication side effects, or cardiac pathology.

5. Marfan syndrome present: Marfan syndrome is a genetic disorder that affects the connective tissues in the body, including the heart valves and aorta. It can lead to cardiovascular complications, including abnormalities on an ECG.

instruction: If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.
input: Hi doctor,I am a 23 year old male, a third-year medical student. For the past seven days, I have had an increased urgency and frequency to urinate. I can go even more than 30 times a day - majority of these times, I feel an increased urgency. However, when I go, only a small amount or drops come out. For the past two to three days, the urgency kind of feels to be getting worse, I feel as if I will not be able to hold it. However, I am still able to as there is no leaking. There is no burning or irritation or any discharge. No recent sexual encounters and no other associated symptoms. I take Coveram 10/10 for essential hypertension and Valdoxan 25 because I also do suffer from anxiety. I have been under stress lately as I was doing my exams this past week and finished today. I have done a few tests at my family doctor: Last week I did a dipstick which was normal apart from +1 protein. Voiding bladder US was normal (450 mL pre voiding, 45 mL post voiding). An initial urine culture was normal according to my doctor. Yesterday, I performed another dipstick and urine culture. The dipstick was normal, and early urine microscopy showed 10 to 100 white cell count. We are waiting for the cultures to return. Due to the result of the white cell count, my doctor said it would be worth a try to undergo a 5-day course of antibiotics (Keflex).Today is my third day of antibiotic treatment, symptoms are largely the same. Today, I attempted to hold my bladder. It felt fine in the morning but as the day went on, my symptoms returned and I am finding it harder to hold my bladder. Also, for the first time, I tried going for a run. The entire time I felt a heaviness in my bladder and felt a strong urge to urinate, even though I went before my run began. What do you think could be going on? My doctor believes that it is either a UTI, or most likely, a hypersensitive bladder due to exam stress. However, there have been days where I have not felt stress at all yet symptoms have continued. I am really worried as I want to go back to work in five days and I do not think I will be able to manage the way things are at the moment. My family doctor does think this will settle down now that I have finished exams. Do you think there is a chance it could? I have mentioned this query to another doctor online, and he believed it may be due to an overactive bladder. However, since I am relatively young to receive this diagnosis, I wanted a second opinion, if that is alright. Do you think this could be OAB? I am worried that it could be something serious, like multiple sclerosis. One and a half years ago, I had an episode of sudden onset numbness in one arm and fearing the same thing, I ended up having an MRI of my brain and lumbar spine which both came back negative. Do you think this could be MS?

To protect your eyes from computer screen damage, here are some tips:

I call his office and the office manager said that she would ask him about it. When I called the next day she said that he did not make a mistake and I asked for an explanation and was told that he did not give one.I started to feel sick a few days later and panic attacks actually started to increase the day that I talk to his office manager. 1. Ahmed Valve Implant: The Ahmed valve implant is a traditional surgical option for treating glaucoma. It involves placing a small, silicone-based valve within the eye to help regulate intraocular pressure. While it has been used for many years, it does have potential risks, including infection, bleeding, and adverse effects on vision.

2. MIGS (Minimally Invasive Glaucoma Surgery): MIGS procedures, such as Xen Gel Stent and InnFocus Microshunt, are newer minimally invasive options for treating glaucoma. These procedures aim to reduce intraocular pressure by improving the drainage of aqueous humor from the eye. They are less invasive than traditional surgeries and have a lower risk of complications. However, they may not be suitable for all patients, and the effectiveness can vary depending on the severity of the glaucoma.

Considering the options, it would be best to consult with a glaucoma specialist who can evaluate your mother's specific case and recommend the most appropriate treatment plan. They

input: Hello doctor,I have stretch marks. Why these appear? And how it can be prevented. Please give me an idea of avoiding this disease.
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:
Hello doctor,I have stretch marks. Why these appear? And how it can be prevented. Please give me an idea of avoiding this disease.

### Response:Stretch marks, also known as striae, are a common skin condition that occurs when the connective tissue in the skin is stretched beyond its limits. This can happen due to rapid growth, pregnancy, weight gain, or hormonal changes.

There are several factors that contribute to the development of stretch marks:

1. Genetics: Some people are more prone to developing stretch marks compared to others.
2. Hormonal changes: During puberty, pregnancy, or hormonal imbalances, there is an increase in certain hormones that can lead to stretch marks.
3. Friction and pressure: Stretch marks can occur when there is constant friction or pressure on the skin, such as from sports or weightlifting.
4. Certain medications: Some medications, such as corticosteroids, can cause stretch marks.

To prevent stretch marks, it is important to maintain a healthy lifestyle and avoid excessive stretching of the skin. Here are some tips:

1. Maintain a healthy weight: If you are overweight or obese, losing weight gradually and maintaining a healthy weight can help prevent stretch marks during periods of rapid weight gain.
2. Moisturize regularly: Keeping the skin well-hydrated and moisturized can help reduce the appearance of stretch marks

### Response:Based on your description, it seems like you are experiencing dental sensitivity. Dental sensitivity can be caused by various factors such as tooth decay, gum recession, or exposure of the dentin (the inner layer of the tooth).

To alleviate the discomfort, you can try the following steps:

1. Brush your teeth gently using a soft-bristled toothbrush and fluoride toothpaste.
2. Avoid acidic and sugary foods and drinks, as they can further erode enamel and increase sensitivity.
3. Use a toothpaste specifically designed for sensitive teeth.
4. Rinse your mouth with saltwater solution (mix half a teaspoon of salt in a glass of warm water and rinse) after meals.
5. Consider using desensitizing toothpaste or gel, which contains ingredients that help reduce sensitivity over time.
6. Visit your dentist for a professional cleaning and evaluation. They may also recommend other treatments depending on the underlying cause of your sensitivity.

Please note that this response is not a substitute for professional medical advice. It is important to consult with a dentist for an accurate diagnosis and appropriate treatment plan.

Tretinoin is a retinoid medication commonly used to treat acne and improve the appearance of fine lines and wrinkles. It works by increasing the turnover of skin cells, which helps to unclog pores and reduce the appearance of acne.

I find her too short compared to her friends, my wife is only 5 feet tall and I myself is 5\7". Is this the reason she is not growing, since last 4 to 5 months her height is the same, or due to adenoids or medication which she took in the past?What should we do regarding her height? Swimming four days a week can contribute to overall fitness and muscle strength, which can also support healthy growth.

### Response:Based on the symptoms you described, it is possible that you have developed Sjogren's syndrome. Sjogren's syndrome is an autoimmune disorder characterized by dry eyes and mouth, as well as photosensitivity.

The treatment for Sjogren's syndrome depends on the severity of your symptoms and any underlying causes. Here are some general treatment options:

1. Artificial tears: Using over-the-counter artificial tears can help relieve dryness in the eyes.

4. Systemic medications: In more severe cases, your doctor may prescribe medications such as corticosteroids or immunosuppressants to reduce inflammation and manage symptoms.
5. Dry mouth relief: There are various strategies to relieve dry mouth, including drinking plenty of water, avoiding caffeine and alcohol, using sugar-free gum or candy, and using saliva substitutes if recommended by your doctor.

### Response:As a doctor, I would need more information about the gaps between your teeth and their severity in order to provide a proper recommendation. However, there are several options available for closing gaps between teeth. The most common methods include:

1. Dental Bridges: This involves placing artificial teeth over the gap to bridge it.
2. Dental Implants: These are small titanium posts that are inserted into the jawbone to replace the missing tooth root. Crowns are then placed on top of the implants to create a natural-looking tooth.
3. Dentures: These are removable false teeth that can be used to replace multiple missing teeth.
4. Orthodontics: If the gaps are due to misalignment of the teeth, orthodontic treatment such as braces or Invisalign can help straighten the teeth and close the gaps.

It is important to consult with a dentist who can evaluate your specific situation and recommend the most appropriate treatment plan.

Hello doctor,I had chest pain. In my 2D echo report, septum jerky is given. What does is it mean? The doctor said the heart is fine.

### Response:The term "septum jerky" refers to an abnormal movement or displacement of the interatrial septum, which is the wall that separates the left and right atria of the heart. It can be seen on a 2D echo report as a wavy or jerky line.

In most cases, a septum jerky finding is not indicative of a significant cardiac issue. It is often associated with physiological changes or variations in the structure of the heart rather than a pathological condition.

However, further evaluation and assessment by a healthcare professional is still necessary to determine the cause and significance of the septum jerky finding. It is important to consult with your doctor for a comprehensive evaluation and interpretation of your specific case.

input: Hello doctor,I am 20 years old and I have myopia (-3,50 ). I always avoided smoking, lived a healthy lifestyle and ate a balanced diet but my vision just got worse. I just became worried about my vision. What else can I do to stop this progress?
raw_output:

### Instruction:

### Input:
Hello doctor,I am 20 years old and I have myopia (-3,50 ). I always avoided smoking, lived a healthy lifestyle and ate a balanced diet but my vision just got worse. I just became worried about my vision. What else can I do to stop this progress?

### Response:As a doctor, I understand your concern about the worsening of your vision. Myopia, also known as nearsightedness, is a common refractive error where objects up close are clear while objects in the distance appear blurry.

While living a healthy lifestyle and maintaining good nutrition can help support overall eye health, there are additional measures you can take to slow down the progression of myopia in certain cases. These include:

1. Regular Eye Exams: It is important to have regular eye exams to monitor the progression of your myopia and make any necessary adjustments to your eyewear.

2. Contact Lenses: Wearing contact lenses can help correct your vision and reduce the progression of myopia. Different types of contact lenses, such as multifocal or orthokeratology (ORK) lenses, can be prescribed to address both distance and near vision issues.

3. Ortho-K Treatment: Orthokeratology (ORK) is a non-surgical procedure where rigid gas permeable contact lenses are worn overnight to reshape the cornea and correct refractive errors, including myopia. This method has shown promise in slowing down the progression of myopia in some cases.

4. Atropine Drops

### Response:Based on the description and the attached image, the white raised line on the left side of your tongue could be indicative of a condition called geographic tongue. Geographic tongue is a common benign condition characterized by red, rough, and scaly patches on the tongue. The name "geographic" comes from the appearance of these patches, which resemble maps or landforms.

It is important to note that geographic tongue is not contagious or cancerous. However, it can cause discomfort and pain, especially when eating or drinking hot or cold foods and beverages.

If you suspect you have geographic tongue, I recommend scheduling an appointment with a healthcare professional for a proper diagnosis and further evaluation. They may also want to rule out other potential causes of tongue pain, such as infections or inflammatory conditions.

When we consulted doctors earlier they suggested using eye drops than surgery. So we have been using Travo Z and Tear Drops daily and she is also able to see properly. So we have been using Travo Z and Tear Drops daily and she is also able to see properly. Since one week she is experiencing pain in her eyes and has trouble looking at the light directly. Her eyes have also turned reddish. Please help.

### Response:Based on the symptoms described, it seems that your grandmother may be experiencing a condition called angle-closure glaucoma. This is a type of glaucoma where the drainage angle of the eye becomes blocked, leading to increased pressure inside the eye. The symptoms of pain, redness, and difficulty looking at lights directly can occur when the blockage occurs.

Angle-closure glaucoma is typically treated with surgery to restore the normal drainage of the eye. However, since your grandmother has been using eye drops (Travo Z and Tear Drops) for the past three years, it is possible that the condition has progressed to the point where surgery is no longer effective.

I would recommend consulting with an ophthalmologist as soon as possible to evaluate your grandmother's condition and determine the best course of action. The ophthalmologist will be able to assess the severity of the blockage and recommend appropriate treatment options, which may include surgery or alternative medications.

input: Hi doctor,I want to know about body lift surgery procedure. I have lost weight of 50 kilograms. I want to get a full body life. How many surgeries do I need? How are they divided? How much time does it take for recovery?
raw_output:

### Input:
Hi doctor,I want to know about body lift surgery procedure. I have lost weight of 50 kilograms. I want to get a full body life. How many surgeries do I need? How are they divided? How much time does it take for recovery?

### Response:Body lift surgery, also known as mastopexy, is a procedure that involves removing excess skin and fat from the upper and lower body to improve contour and shape. The number of surgeries needed depends on the extent of skin laxity and the areas being treated. In your case, considering your weight loss and the need for a full body lift, multiple surgeries may be required.

The surgeries can be divided into different regions, such as the upper body (including the breasts), lower body, and posterior body (including the buttocks and thighs). Each region may require its own surgery, depending on the specific areas of concern and the amount of excess skin.

The recovery time for body lift surgery can vary but typically takes several weeks to months. During the initial recovery phase, you may experience swelling, pain, and discomfort. It is important to follow post-operative instructions, including wound care and physical therapy, to aid in the healing process and ensure optimal results.

It is essential to consult with a board-certified plastic surgeon who can evaluate your specific case and provide personalized recommendations regarding the number of surgeries, their division, and the recovery process.

### Response:Based on the symptoms you described, it is possible that you are experiencing a condition called "tinea corporis," also known as ringworm. This is a fungal infection that can affect the skin and is commonly characterized by red, scaly patches with well-defined borders.

The presence of white tiny particles on your penis skin could be due to the fungal spores spreading from the affected area on your body. Itching forehead skin could be a result of the fungal infection spreading to this area as well.

To treat tinea corporis, it is important to identify and eliminate the fungal infection. I recommend visiting a healthcare professional for an accurate diagnosis and appropriate treatment plan. They may prescribe antifungal medications such as clotrimazole, miconazole, or terbinafine, which can be applied directly to the affected areas. In some cases, oral antifungal medications may be necessary.

In the meantime, you can continue to apply Candid B as directed, but it is not a sufficient treatment for tinea corporis. Candid B is typically used for yeast infections, not fungal infections.

Please consult a healthcare professional for an accurate diagnosis and appropriate treatment plan.

Colon hydrotherapy is a specific technique within colon cleansing where a machine is used to inject warm water into the colon to flush out waste materials. This procedure is usually performed by a healthcare professional under medical supervision.

The effectiveness of colon hydrotherapy depends on various factors, including the individual's health condition and the reason for undergoing the procedure. In the case of chronic constipation, colon hydrotherapy can be beneficial as it helps to remove waste materials and stimulate bowel movements. However, it is important to note that chronic constipation is often a complex condition and may require a comprehensive treatment approach involving lifestyle modifications, dietary changes, and other medical interventions. Therefore, it is recommended to consult with a healthcare professional to determine the most appropriate treatment plan for your specific situation.

The pain you feel during a center split is likely due to the increased stress on the hip joint during this movement. The stopping pain in your outer hip with no stretch in your inner thigh suggests that the pain is coming from the iliotibial (IT) band, which is a thick band of tissue that runs from the hip to the shinbone.

1. Stretching: Performing specific stretches for the IT band can help improve flexibility and relieve pain. Some effective stretches include the "butterfly stretch," "standing hip flexor stretch," and "side-lying hip flexor stretch."

3. Modify activities: If certain movements or activities exacerbate your sympt

instruction: If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.
input: Hello doctor,I have complicated migraines, simple partial seizures and are controlled by Lamictal. I have a long time pain from sound intake and it has worsened into my face. Other sensory triggers the pain. It has become just way too much to handle. I sought advice from friends and groups and nurses, that have trigeminal neuralgia and they suggest Carbamazepine.I learned it lowers Lamictal. I contacted pharmacy that said many will test blood serum of Lamictal and then add Carbamazepine and adjust Lamictal to therapeutic levels.My doctor is a bit concerned. She is not a pain doctor or neurologist. I am waiting to see one. But my condition makes it hard to travel in a car. My doctor asked I seek advice. Do you agree that checking the serum and adjusting is fine to do, in order to take Carbamazepine?The second option is Oxcarbazepine. In your experience is it a good pain drug for TN and does it mess up Lamictal? I found a study that said it did not.I was thinking I could start it now while I wait on Lamictal levels. And see if it helps. Just really struggling. Pain cream not helping much in certain places. My old neurologist wanted me to lower Glutamate as much as I could and suggested Namenda at one point. I know many people are on two and three drugs. I hope to try injections for the pain soon. Do you have any suggestions?
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:
Hello doctor,I have complicated migraines, simple partial seizures and are controlled by Lamictal. I have a long time pain from sound intake and it has worsened into my face. Other sensory triggers the pain. It has become just way too much to handle. I sought advice from friends and groups and nurses, that have trigeminal neuralgia and they suggest Carbamazepine.I learned it lowers Lamictal. I contacted pharmacy that said many will test blood serum of Lamictal and then add Carbamazepine and adjust Lamictal to therapeutic levels.My doctor is a bit concerned. She is not a pain doctor or neurologist. I am waiting to see one. But my condition makes it hard to travel in a car. My doctor asked I seek advice. Do you agree that checking the serum and adjusting is fine to do, in order to take Carbamazepine?The second option is Oxcarbazepine. In your experience is it a good pain drug for TN and does it mess up Lamictal? I found a study that said it did not.I was thinking I could start it now while I wait on Lamictal levels. And see if it helps. Just really struggling. Pain cream not helping much in certain places. My old neurologist wanted me to lower Glutamate as much as I could and suggested Namenda at one point. I know many people are on two and three drugs. I hope to try injections for the pain soon. Do you have any suggestions?

### Response:As a medical expert, I can provide some information on the topic you mentioned.

Trigeminal neuralgia (TN) is a condition characterized by severe facial pain. It is important to note that TN is a separate condition from migraines or simple partial seizures.

In terms of managing TN, there are several medications that can be used. Carbamazepine and Oxcarbazepine are two commonly prescribed medications for TN. Both medications belong to the same class of drugs called anticonvulsants.

Carbamazepine is often used as a first-line treatment for TN because it has been shown to effectively reduce pain in many patients. However, it can also lower the levels of Lamictal (another anticonvulsant medication) in the blood. This is why it is important to monitor Lamictal levels before starting Carbamazepine and adjust the Lamictal dosage if necessary.

Oxcarbazepine is another anticonvulsant medication that can be used as an alternative to Carbamazepine. It has a similar effectiveness in reducing TN pain but may not have the same impact on Lamictal levels.

In terms of adjusting Lamictal dosage while adding Carbamazepine or Oxcarbazepine, it is generally recommended

### Response:Based on the information provided, it appears that your hCG levels have been increasing steadily until the last measurement at 3900. While it is concerning that your hCG levels have not doubled properly, it does not necessarily mean that you will miscarry.

HCG (human chorionic gonadotropin) is a hormone produced by the developing placenta. Its levels typically double every 48-72 hours during the first trimester of pregnancy. However, there can be natural variations in hCG levels, and not all pregnancies follow a perfectly linear increase.

To assess the health of your pregnancy, it is important to consider other factors such as the gestational age of the fetus, ultrasound findings, and any symptoms you may be experiencing. A follow-up ultrasound can provide more information about the growth and well-being of your fetus.

I would recommend scheduling an appointment with your healthcare provider to discuss these results and any concerns you may have. They will be able to evaluate your specific situation and provide appropriate guidance and further testing if necessary.

input: Hi doctor,I am having issues with sleeping. I am exhausted all day every day, sleep 6 to 9 hours every night and take 2 to 3 hours nap every day. I am unable to control falling asleep. I am not on any medications.
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:
Hi doctor,I am having issues with sleeping. I am exhausted all day every day, sleep 6 to 9 hours every night and take 2 to 3 hours nap every day. I am unable to control falling asleep. I am not on any medications.

### Response:Based on the patient's description, it seems that they are experiencing excessive daytime sleepiness and difficulty controlling their sleep. These symptoms can be indicative of a sleep disorder called narcolepsy. Narcolepsy is a neurological disorder that affects the control of sleep and wakefulness.

To further evaluate the patient's condition, I would recommend the following steps:

1. Medical History: Gather information about the patient's sleep patterns, including the duration and quality of sleep, as well as any other symptoms they may be experiencing.

2. Polysomnography: This is a test that records brain activity, eye movements, heart rate, breathing, and other physiological functions during sleep. It can help identify any abnormalities in the sleep architecture and provide a diagnosis.

3. Multiple Sleep Latency Test (MSLT): This test measures how quickly a person falls asleep during the day and assesses their ability to resist sleep. It can help determine if excessive daytime sleepiness is due to narcolepsy.

4. Epworth Sleepiness Scale: This questionnaire evaluates the degree of daytime sleepiness and can provide additional information about the patient's sleep patterns.

5. Consultation with a Sleep Specialist: It is important to involve a healthcare professional

This can lead to symptoms such as difficulty in filling the heart with blood during diastole (the relaxation phase of the heartbeat).

ECG (Electrocardiogram): An ECG records the electrical activity of the heart and can detect abnormalities in the heart's rhythm. PVCs can be associated with restrictive cardiomyopathy, but they are not specific to this condition.

Instead of combining Levofloxacin with Ibuprofen and Dexamethasone, it would be better to use alternative pain

### Response:Based on the symptoms you described, it is possible that you are experiencing a urinary tract infection (UTI). The pain in your vagina, burning sensation while urinating, and frequent urination are common symptoms of a UTI.

To confirm the diagnosis and prescribe appropriate treatment, I would recommend visiting a healthcare professional, such as a gynecologist or primary care physician. They will be able to perform a physical examination and possibly order some tests, such as a urine culture or urine analysis, to confirm the presence of a UTI.

In the meantime, there are some self-care measures you can take to alleviate the symptoms:

1. Drink plenty of water: Staying hydrated can help flush out bacteria from your urinary tract.
2. Urinate frequently: Try to urinate when you feel the need to, as it helps flush out bacteria from the urinary tract.
3. Avoid irritants: Steer clear of irritating substances like bubble baths, harsh soaps, and perfumed products that may irritate the genital area.
4. Wear breathable underwear: Opt for cotton underwear to allow air circulation and reduce moisture in the genital area.
5. Take probiotics: Pro

input: Hello doctor,I had protected sex before two years. As I recall she was on the top and then later I was on top of her. During the act, my condom slipped, but there was no exposure to my bare penis. I could not achieve an erection, so she removed the condom and applied lotion on my penis. My question is,1. Can her vaginal fluids enter my exposed penis as she applied lotion, making me infective (unknown status)?2. I had two p24 tests done at four and nine weeks. Both came negative. Should I go to 12 weeks or is this conclusive? Is there any chance of turning negative to positive?3. I feel swollen lymph node in my neck which occurred close to 12 weeks now. Am I HIV infective? Please help with your reply, and I am getting stressed.

Can her vaginal fluids enter my exposed penis as she applied lotion, making me infective (unknown status)?2. I had two p24 tests done at four and nine weeks. Both came negative. Should I go to 12 weeks or is this conclusive? Is there any chance of turning negative to positive?3. I feel swollen lymph node in my neck which occurred close to 12 weeks now. Am I HIV infective? ### Response:1. Based on the information you provided, there is a risk of exposure to HIV if her vaginal fluids entered your exposed penis. It is important to note that the use of a condom is the best way to prevent HIV transmission during sexual activity.

2. The two p24 tests done at four and nine weeks are not conclusive for determining HIV infection. While they can provide some information, a conclusive diagnosis can only be made after conducting additional tests such as the Western blot test.

3. Swollen lymph nodes in the neck can be a sign of various conditions, including infection. However, it does not necessarily mean that you are HIV infective. Other factors such as viral infections, allergies, or even stress can cause swollen lymph nodes. It is recommended to consult with a healthcare professional for further evaluation and diagnosis.

In conclusion, based on the information provided, there is a possibility of exposure to HIV due to the slipped condom during protected sex. Additional testing and evaluation by a healthcare professional are recommended to determine the definitive status.

I took Ibuprofen and Voltarin Samuel gel but made no difference to the pain.

This is characterized by pain and swelling at the outside part of the elbow. The symptoms described, such as worsening pain with flexion and extension of the arm, along with radiating pain down the forearm, are consistent with this condition.

Lateral epicondylitis is commonly known as tennis elbow and is often caused by repetitive strain or overuse of the forearm muscles. It can occur in individuals who engage in activities like tennis, golf, or any other sport that involves repetitive wrist and forearm movements.

To confirm the diagnosis and determine the appropriate treatment plan, it would be best for the patient to consult with a healthcare professional, such as an orthopedic specialist or sports medicine physician. In the meantime, the patient can try some conservative measures to alleviate symptoms. These may include resting the affected arm, avoiding activities that worsen the pain, using ice packs or heat therapy, performing gentle stretching exercises for the forearm and elbow, and taking over-the-counter pain medications

Immediately in about 15 minutes after the procedure, I experienced shortness of breath, burning sensation in muscles, swelling of legs, fatigue, and diarrhea. input: Hello doctor,I am 58 years old. I have some very minor tingle in my right second toe. I am very healthy with no medicines and no other symptoms. It started with unilateral tinnitus. MRI of the spine showed moderate to severe stenosis spine. I do exercise, and running, and my neurologist says this might be normal. I had a concussion when I was 17 and spent a day in the hospital.My MRI brain is obviously abnormal with white matter. What is the likelihood of MS? I had an MRI in 2015 and said chronic microvascular changes. MRI of a couple of weeks ago said no tumor on auditory nerves. Please explain.
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:
Hello doctor,I am 58 years old. I have some very minor tingle in my right second toe. I am very healthy with no medicines and no other symptoms. It started with unilateral tinnitus. MRI of the spine showed moderate to severe stenosis spine. I do exercise, and running, and my neurologist says this might be normal. I had a concussion when I was 17 and spent a day in the hospital.My MRI brain is obviously abnormal with white matter. What is the likelihood of MS? I had an MRI in 2015 and said chronic microvascular changes. MRI of a couple of weeks ago said no tumor on auditory nerves. Please explain.

### Response:Based on the information provided, it is difficult to determine the likelihood of multiple sclerosis (MS) without further evaluation and diagnostic tests. MS is a neurological condition characterized by inflammation and damage to the protective covering of nerve fibers in the central nervous system.

The presence of tingling in the right second toe, along with moderate to severe spinal stenosis, could potentially be related to nerve compression or irritation. However, these symptoms alone are not sufficient to diagnose MS.

The fact that you had a concussion in the past and experienced tinnitus suggests that there may be a connection between your neurological symptoms and previous head trauma. It is important to consider other possible causes for your symptoms, such as vestibular schwannomas (acoustic neuromas), which can present with tinnitus and neurological deficits.

To determine the likelihood of MS, additional diagnostic tests such as magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain and spinal cord, along with cerebrospinal fluid analysis, would be necessary. These tests can help identify characteristic findings seen in MS, such as demyelination and plaques in the central nervous system.

I recommend consulting with a neurologist who can evaluate your symptoms, medical history

input: Hi doctor,My sister is 18 years old, and she has never had periods. Recently, we did a test which said, 46, XY (20), 20 cells were counted, all cells showed 46 chromosomes. Small chromosomal anomalies and small clonal population may not be detected using the standard methods employed. Could you please explain what does it mean? What can be done for her? Will she be able to have kids?
raw_output:

Hi doctor,My sister is 18 years old, and she has never had periods. Recently, we did a test which said, 46, XY (20), 20 cells were counted, all cells showed 46 chromosomes. Small chromosomal anomalies and small clonal population may not be detected using the standard methods employed. Could you please explain what does it mean? What can be done for her? Will she be able to have kids?

### Response:Based on the information provided, it seems that your sister may have a condition called Turner syndrome. Turner syndrome is a genetic disorder that occurs in females when one of the X chromosomes is partially or completely missing.

The karyotype result of 46, XY (20), 20 cells with all cells showing 46 chromosomes indicates that there is a missing or structurally altered X chromosome. This is consistent with Turner syndrome.

In terms of what can be done for her, the mainstay of treatment for Turner syndrome is hormone replacement therapy (HRT). HRT involves taking estrogen supplements to help with the development of secondary sexual characteristics and to reduce the risk of certain health issues associated with Turner syndrome, such as infertility and cardiovascular problems.

As for your sister's ability to have children, it depends on various factors such as the severity of the Turner syndrome and other individual circumstances. In some cases, individuals with mild Turner syndrome may still be able to conceive naturally, while others may require assisted reproductive technologies like in vitro fertilization (IVF) to achieve pregnancy. It would be best for your sister to consult with a reproductive specialist who can provide more specific guidance based on her individual situation.

input: Hello doctor,I am a 33 year old female. I got my cavity filled two days back. Now, it hurts when I drink cold stuff. Is there anything I can do?

Hello doctor,I am a 33 year old female. I got my cavity filled two days back. Now, it hurts when I drink cold stuff. Is there anything I can do?

### Response:As a doctor, I would recommend the following steps to alleviate the pain caused by drinking cold stuff after getting a cavity filled:

1. Take over-the-counter pain relievers: You can take acetaminophen (such as Tylenol) or nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) like ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin) to reduce pain and inflammation.

2. Rinse your mouth with saltwater: Mix half a teaspoon of salt in a glass of warm water and gently rinse your mouth several times a day. This can help reduce inflammation and relieve pain.

3. Avoid cold drinks: It is advisable to avoid consuming cold or iced drinks until the sensitivity in your tooth subsides. Opt for warm or room temperature beverages instead.

4. Use a straw: If you must drink cold drinks, using a straw can help minimize direct contact between the cold liquid and the filled tooth, reducing the potential for discomfort.

5. Practice good oral hygiene: Make sure to maintain good oral hygiene by brushing your teeth at least twice a day and flossing daily. This will help promote healing and prevent further issues.

6. Follow up with your dent

input: Hello doctor,I missed my period last month and after the first late day I took a pregnancy test and it said not pregnant. So I waited for a few more days to go by to take another and it said positive so from that day I scheduled a follow-up appointment and when I went to get an ultrasound they told me that there was nothing there. So she predicted that I may be early, so she used the camera and she still did not see anything. She told me to undergo a urine test and it came out negative meaning I am not pregnant. I left there and took another test at home and it said negative. It has been a whole month and I still do not have my period. What could be wrong with my body?
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:
Hello doctor,I missed my period last month and after the first late day I took a pregnancy test and it said not pregnant. So I waited for a few more days to go by to take another and it said positive so from that day I scheduled a follow-up appointment and when I went to get an ultrasound they told me that there was nothing there. So she predicted that I may be early, so she used the camera and she still did not see anything. She told me to undergo a urine test and it came out negative meaning I am not pregnant. I left there and took another test at home and it said negative. It has been a whole month and I still do not have my period. What could be wrong with my body?

### Response:Based on the information provided, there are a few possible explanations for your situation:

1. False positive pregnancy test: It is possible that the initial positive pregnancy test was due to a false positive result. This can occur if the test is performed too early after missed periods or if the hCG levels in the urine are elevated for another reason, such as a urinary tract infection or hormonal imbalance.

2. Ectopic pregnancy: Another possibility is an ectopic pregnancy, where the fertilized egg implants outside of the uterus, usually in the fallopian tube. This can cause a positive pregnancy test but may not result in a viable pregnancy. An ectopic pregnancy can be life-threatening if left untreated, so it is important to seek medical attention promptly.

3. Miscarriage: If you experienced a missed period and then had a positive pregnancy test, it is possible that you miscarried the pregnancy without realizing it. Miscarriages can occur early in pregnancy and may not always be accompanied by noticeable symptoms.

4. Hormonal imbalance: Hormonal imbalances can also cause irregular menstrual cycles and missed periods. This could be due to factors such as polycyst

### Response:Based on the information provided, it seems that you may be experiencing premature ejaculation (PE) and erectile dysfunction (ED). PE is characterized by the inability to delay ejaculation for an acceptable duration, usually ejaculating within 1 minute of vaginal penetration. ED refers to the difficulty in achieving or maintaining an erection.

There are several potential causes for these issues, including psychological factors, anxiety, depression, or relationship problems. It is important to rule out any underlying medical conditions that could contribute to these symptoms, such as hormonal imbalances, medication side effects, or neurological disorders.

I would recommend seeking help from a healthcare professional, such as a urologist or a sex therapist, who can further evaluate your situation and provide appropriate treatment options. They may suggest techniques to help you delay ejaculation, improve erectile function, or explore any potential underlying causes. It is important to address these concerns as they can have a significant impact on your sexual satisfaction and relationship with your partner.

I do not understand the concept of SPF 25, 30, 50 and 60.

### Response:As a doctor, I can provide you with some guidance on choosing the right sunblock cream.

SPF stands for Sun Protection Factor, which indicates the level of protection against UVB (burning) and UVA (aging) rays provided by the sunscreen. The higher the SPF number, the longer it takes for your skin to burn. For example, an SPF of 25 means it takes approximately 25 times longer for your skin to burn compared to if you weren't wearing any sunscreen.

Here are some recommendations based on your description:

1. Choose a broad-spectrum sunscreen: Look for a sunscreen that protects against both UVA and UVB rays. This will provide better overall protection for your skin.

2. Consider your skin type and sensitivity: If you have sensitive skin, you may want to opt for a hypoallergenic or fragrance-free sunscreen to minimize any potential irritation.

3. Apply sunscreen generously: Remember to apply a thick layer of sunscreen to all exposed areas of your face, neck, and body. This will ensure adequate coverage and protection.

4. Reapply sunscreen regularly: It is important to reapply sunscreen every two hours, especially if you are sweating or swimming, as these activities can reduce its effectiveness.

input: Hi doctor,We have a regular contraceptive pill and an emergency contraceptive pill. I-pill is an emergency contraceptive pill. What is the difference between them? Which one is taken after unprotected sex to avoid pregnancy?
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:
Hi doctor,We have a regular contraceptive pill and an emergency contraceptive pill. I-pill is an emergency contraceptive pill. What is the difference between them? Which one is taken after unprotected sex to avoid pregnancy?

### Response:The difference between a regular contraceptive pill and an emergency contraceptive pill (I-pill) is that the emergency contraceptive pill is taken after unprotected sex to prevent pregnancy. It contains higher doses of hormones compared to regular contraceptive pills and works by delaying or inhibiting ovulation, preventing fertilization of eggs.

The regular contraceptive pill, on the other hand, is taken daily over an extended period of time to prevent pregnancy by inhibiting ovulation, thickening cervical mucus to block sperm entry, and thinning the uterine lining to prevent implantation of a fertilized egg.

In the case of unprotected sex, the emergency contraceptive pill should be taken as soon as possible, preferably within 72 hours (3 days) of intercourse. It is important to note that emergency contraception is most effective when taken within the first 24 hours after unprotected sex.

### Response:As a doctor, I can provide you with some information regarding conception after removing the Mirena IUD. 

The Mirena IUD is a form of contraception that works by releasing progestin hormone into the uterus. It can help regulate your menstrual cycle and may delay or even stop periods in some women. However, it does not protect against sexually transmitted infections (STIs) or HIV.

In terms of conception, it is generally recommended to wait for a few days after removal of the Mirena IUD before trying to conceive. ### Response:Unilateral ptosis, or drooping of one eyelid, can have various causes. It is important to determine the underlying cause before considering any treatment options. Some possible causes of unilateral ptosis include:

1. Eye muscle weakness: Weakness in the muscles that control eyelid movement can lead to ptosis. This can be caused by conditions such as myasthenia gravis, oculomotor nerve palsy, or muscle weakness due to aging.

2. Eye socket disorders: Conditions like orbital tumors, fractures, or inflammation of the eye socket (orbitalitis) can cause ptosis.

3. Eye diseases: Certain eye diseases like glaucoma, cataracts, or eyelid skin conditions like blepharitis can contribute to ptosis.

4. Neurological disorders: Conditions like Bell's palsy or nerve damage from stroke can result in ptosis.

To determine the cause of your ptosis, it is recommended to consult with an ophthalmologist. They will perform a thorough examination, including evaluating the muscle strength of your eyes, assessing the structure of your eyelids, and may order additional tests if needed.

input: Hi doctor,My mom is 83 years old. She had a bad fall 1.5 years ago and suffered with a head injury with little internal bleeding and a broken arm. While in hospital, she contracted C.diff and has had several recurring bouts with it. She has had a transplant and so far she is doing well with no recurrence. She also has a fistula near the rectum from an abscess. They put in a tube to keep it open and flowing. She has always had bouts of constipation and diarrhea for years before the accident. Her cognitive functions have been diminishing. One of my brothers is living with her and care taking her for full time.She is very weak, but can walk with the aid of a walker. Before the accident, she was fine. But, she may have shown a few signs of slight memory issues and balance prior to the accident as well. Our main issue right now is loose stools with some fecal incontinence. The doctor said that the fecal incontinence is because of a weak rectum that will not hold back fecal matter. Also, the fistula is always draining. When her stools are normal, she has good energy and cognitive function. When she has loose stools, she is very weak and can hardly stand or walk. Her cognitive function is a lot worse. She gets very confused about daily items and memory issues.We are looking for supplements to keep her regular and avoid the loose stool episodes. These are recurring every other week. Being so weak at the time of an episode, the toilet and the surrounding area get very filthy. She has little control and not able to clean herself properly. Her diet is pretty good. We are trying to keep dairy items away, limiting sugar and some carbohydrates as best as we can.We are giving her Metamucil when she has loose stools as well as some ammonium. This seems to have very limited success. She is on a blood pressure medicine as well as on Coumadin. So, we have to watch for interactions between everything. Regarding supplements, right now she is taking Alpha-GPC, Prevagen and multivitamins B for cognitive help, Fish oil, turmeric and Centrum multivitamins.Any help or suggestions to prevent the loose stools without creating constipation would be appreciated. I would also like to increase her core energy, so she will feel more like moving around. We have a physical therapist at once a week.

### Response:Based on the description you provided, it seems like you are experiencing post-inflammatory hyperpigmentation (PIH) as a result of popping pimples. PIH is a common skin condition where the area of inflammation becomes darker or more pigmented than the surrounding skin.

To address this issue, I would recommend the following steps:

1. Avoid picking or popping pimples: It is important to avoid touching or squeezing any pimples on your face or upper back. This will help prevent further inflammation and reduce the risk of developing dark spots.

2. Use topical treatments: Over-the-counter products containing ingredients such as hydroquinone, kojic acid, or azelaic acid may help lighten the dark spots. These products work by reducing the production of melanin, the pigment responsible for the darkening. Apply these products directly on the affected areas and follow the instructions provided on the packaging.

3. Use sunscreen: It is crucial to protect your skin from the sun's harmful rays. Apply a broad-spectrum sunscreen with an SPF of 30 or higher on a daily basis, even if you are not exposed to the sun directly. This will help prevent further darkening of the skin and reduce the risk

1. Pelvic tilts: Lie on your back with knees bent and feet flat on the floor. Gently tilt your pelvis upward, flattening your lower back against the floor. Hold for a few seconds and then release.

2. Buttock squeezes: While lying on your back, tighten your buttock muscles as if trying to lift your bottom off the ground. Hold for a few seconds and then relax.

3. Hip abduction: Lie on your side with the affected leg bent and the other leg straight. Gently lift the top leg away from the bed or floor, keeping the knee straight. Hold for a few seconds and then lower it back down.

It is important to note that these exercises should be performed slowly and with proper form

Started exercising and lost weight and inches, 198 lbs to 178, 38-inch waist to 32. Symptoms still persisted. The doctor started me on Clomid 50 mg three times per week.Testosterone shot up to 900\s but symptoms persisted although Cialis helped with erection quality, still low libido. Will attach a note with test and A1c results during this time. So, I stopped taking the Clomid in March this year and had my physical last week.The doctor says my testosterone is 570, A1c is 6.0 and everything else looks good. He says since I still have symptoms, that I have testosterone resistance. His analogy was; like diabetics, their bodies produce insulin but just does not know what to do with it.So, his treatment recommendation is TRT testosterone replacement therapy along with Clomid. I am hesitant because I feel this therapy is overused nowadays, and I feel pretty good except my libido.Sought a second opinion today from my urologist, he seemed disinterested in me doing that but said if I try a few injections it would not hurt me, then advised me to run this by an endocrinologist.So I guess in summary:Do you believe that testosterone resistance is a valid diagnosis?If I do try the TRT, can I stop after a few weeks or a few injections and get back to the way I am right now with no permanent issues?Should I just start the Clomid again, or just keep using the Cialis and keep working out and trying to clean up my diet more?Any other thoughts and advise would be appreciated. Thanks.

input: Hello doctor, To start, I have bipolar disorder type II, social and generalized anxiety disorders. Previously, I failed to SSRI medications such as Zoloft, Prozac, Lexapro. I tried Lithium, Depakote, and Carbamazepine with no success. However currently, I take 50 mg of Lamictal and 75 mg Venlafaxine. This treatment kind fits me because I have lessened anxiety levels for sure. It is my first week on Venlafaxine XR. And the second week on Lamictal. In a few days we will increase Lamictal to 100 mg and after two weeks to 200 mg. I also take Tranxene 10 mg if needed, as well as Olanzapine 10 mg. How come I responded to Venlafaxine XR so fast, when I did not respond to SSRI? I lack energy and motivation, should I increase Venlafaxine XR to 150? If so, will it have more effects on my anxiety and depressive episode?

I tried Lithium, Depakote, and Carbamazepine with no success. However currently, I take 50 mg of Lamictal and 75 mg Venlafaxine. This treatment kind fits me because I have lessened anxiety levels for sure. It is my first week on Venlafaxine XR. And the second week on Lamictal. In a few days we will increase Lamictal to 100 mg and after two weeks to 200 mg. I also take Tranxene 10 mg if needed, as well as Olanzapine 10 mg. How come I responded to Venlafaxine XR so fast, when I did not respond to SSRI? I lack energy and motivation, should I increase Venlafaxine XR to 150? ### Response:Based on the information provided, it seems that you have responded well to Venlafaxine XR. This could be due to its mechanism of action as a serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI). SSRIs, such as Zoloft, Prozac, and Lexapro, primarily work by increasing serotonin levels in the brain.

In contrast, Venlafaxine XR contains both serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SNRIs), which increases the availability of both serotonin and norepinephrine in the brain. This dual action may be more effective for individuals who do not respond well to SSRIs.

Regarding your concerns about energy and motivation, it is important to note that individual responses to medication can vary. While some individuals may experience an increase in energy and motivation with Venlafaxine XR, others may not. If you are currently experiencing low energy and motivation, it may be beneficial to discuss this with your prescribing physician. They can evaluate your specific symptoms and determine if an adjustment in dosage is necessary.

Increasing the dose of Venlafaxine XR from 50 mg to 100 mg may have more effects on your anxiety and depress

input: Hi doctor,One year back, while sitting on a chair in office I felt as if my back got stuck and was unable to move. I took two painkillers and managed to sit there for a while, but after two to three hours the pain started radiating to leg. I was diagnosed with moderate disc herniation at L4-L5 and L5-S1. I was advised to take bed rest for three months and felt better after five months. Then I got some manipulation done with my lower back and my condition got worse. After that I had slight pain in my tail bone while walking and the pain got worse when I sit for five minutes. It got radiated to hips, thighs and it was worse when I stood up from a sitting position. Then I left with no option except bed rest for another four months that is a total nine months of bed rest. After that I suddenly started walking two to three hours a day in a stretch and started doing some exercises. After few days of getting my body too much into motion I felt my upper back getting stuck and again was unable to move and the pain radiated to my wrist and hand. Then had bed rest for another 10 days and felt a bit better. But, still in pain and resumed with two to three hours of brisk walking and exercises. I noticed that many joints in my body were making cracking sound while I walk or move my body and they were continuous. They are not going away no matter how much I move that joint, the cracking sound will repeat infinite times whenever I move my body. The cracking sound is mostly from lower and upper back, shoulder, ankle, foot fingers, knees also make that cracking sound and it is painful as well. Cracking sound in knees are felt more when I start walking after being in rest state and frequency of cracking sound reduces after walking for two to three minutes.I got my ESR and CRP checked. They are normal, but there is a slight increase in lymphocytes and RBC. Now, I have been suffering from this continuous cracking sounds and pain in almost all my joints for more than a month now. I also suffer from severe pain in tail bone area. Also suffers from some sensation loss (not persistent) in left side of my upper left leg, pain in groin area (but not anymore), pain in lower back and upper back. Also a few days back a physiotherapist did some manipulation, which again increased my problem and after that when I wake up in morning both my hands are badly at asleep. Doctors say that discs are hydrated and it is rather some other thing which is causing me problems but are unable to diagnose. The amount of rest I have taken and all those manipulations have gone through have only done badly rather than doing any good. I am only 27 years old and unable to do simple tasks like sitting for five minutes. Please help me, what could be the possible reason for all this.I had some back pain three years ago. My lifestyle is also not good. I do not used to any exercise or walk earlier, only sitting on a chair in front of a computer for 10-11 hours. I have also gained weight of 15 kg in 10 months. Right now, I am taking only Vitamin D3 supplement. I am attaching all my reports for your reference.

They are normal, but there is a slight increase in lymphocytes and RBC. Now, I have been suffering from this continuous cracking sounds and pain in almost all my joints for more than a month now. ### Response:Based on the patient's description, it appears that they are experiencing symptoms of a condition called fibromyalgia. Fibromyalgia is a chronic disorder characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain, fatigue, and tenderness in certain areas of the body.

It is important for the patient to consult with a healthcare professional for a proper diagnosis and management plan. Treatment for fibromyalgia typically involves a combination of medication, physical therapy, exercise, and lifestyle modifications.

input: Hello doctor,I concern that I have angle-closure glaucoma. I took a strong sleeping pill called Trazodone one night and woke up with a decreased vision in the right eye. My left eye became bad three weeks later. It has now been three months with no improvement. Fundus and other clinical examinations are normal. However, an OCT showed nerve fiber thinning and ganglion cell thinning.
raw_output:

### Input:

My left eye became bad three weeks later. It has now been three months with no improvement. Fundus and other clinical examinations are normal. However, an OCT showed nerve fiber thinning and ganglion cell thinning.

### Response:Based on the patient's description, it is possible that they have angle-closure glaucoma. Angle-closure glaucoma occurs when the drainage angle of the eye becomes blocked, leading to increased pressure within the eye. This increased pressure can cause optic nerve damage and result in vision loss.

The patient's symptoms of decreased vision in the right eye after taking a strong sleeping pill called Trazodone, followed by worsening vision in the left eye three weeks later, are consistent with the acute angle-closure attack. The lack of improvement after three months suggests ongoing damage to the optic nerve.

The normal fundus and clinical examinations, along with the findings of nerve fiber thinning and ganglion cell thinning on OCT, further support the diagnosis of angle-closure glaucoma.

It is important for the patient to seek immediate medical attention to prevent further damage to the optic nerve. Treatment options for angle-closure glaucoma may include medication, laser therapy, or surgery to improve the drainage angle and reduce intraocular pressure.

### Response:Based on the patient's description, it appears that they have fluid accumulation in the subcoracoid and subdeltoid bursa, as well as the bicep tendon. These findings are suggestive of subcoracoid/subdeltoid bursitis and mild biceps tendinosis.

Subcoracoid/subdeltoid bursitis is an inflammation of the bursa located between the coracoid process of the scapula and the deltoid muscle. It can cause pain, swelling, and limited range of motion in the shoulder joint.

Mild biceps tendinosis refers to the presence of microtears or degeneration of the tendon that attaches the biceps muscle to the shoulder blade. This condition can lead to pain, stiffness, and reduced strength in the shoulder.

Treatment for these conditions typically involves rest, ice, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), and physical therapy exercises to improve range of motion and strength. In some cases, corticosteroid injections may be recommended to reduce inflammation.

It is important for the patient to follow up with their healthcare provider for a proper diagnosis and to discuss appropriate treatment options.

If the material is cementum, it is not necessary to take any specific action as it is a normal part of the tooth structure. However, if you notice any changes or symptoms such as increased sensitivity or pain, it would be advisable to consult with a dentist for further evaluation.
