input: Hello doctor,I suffer from bipolar 2 disorder as well as OCD and social anxiety disorder. I have tried almost all SSRIs, and SNRIs and neither of them have worked for me (for the last 2 1/2 years). I believe that I have treatment-resistant depression because all the medicines are not working. Currently, I am taking 20 mg of Paroxetine (although I already took 40 mg a few months ago, so I already increased the dose as well), 900 mg of Lithium and 1.5 mg of Risperidone. What should I do?
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:

### Input:
Hello doctor,I suffer from bipolar 2 disorder as well as OCD and social anxiety disorder. I have tried almost all SSRIs, and SNRIs and neither of them have worked for me (for the last 2 1/2 years). I believe that I have treatment-resistant depression because all the medicines are not working. Currently, I am taking 20 mg of Paroxetine (although I already took 40 mg a few months ago, so I already increased the dose as well), 900 mg of Lithium and 1.5 mg of Risperidone. What should I do?

### Response:Based on the information provided, it seems that you have been trying various medications for your bipolar 2 disorder, OCD, and social anxiety disorder without success. It is important to discuss this with your treating physician to determine the next steps.

One option that could be considered is switching to a different class of medication or adding an additional medication to your current treatment regimen. There are several alternative treatments that may be effective for treatment-resistant depression, such as:

1. Augmentation therapy: Adding another medication to your current treatment regimen, such as lamotrigine, aripiprazole, or thyroid hormone, can sometimes help improve symptoms.

2. Psychotherapy: Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) or other forms of psychotherapy can be beneficial in managing symptoms and improving overall well-being.

3. Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT): ECT may be considered if other treatments have not been successful. ECT is a procedure where electric currents are passed through the brain to induce controlled seizures.

4. Transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS): TMS uses magnetic fields to stimulate specific areas of the brain. It has been shown to be effective in some cases of treatment-resistant depression.

instruction: If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.
input: Hello doctor,I was diagnosed with a left branch bundle block a few years back. I have been under the care of a cardiologist to make sure my heart is fine since then. I have done stress echos yearly or every two years since and have been told my heart is otherwise fine. I just had to switch the other doctor because of insurance and my new doctor says old stress echos are irrelevant, that only chemical or nuclear echos work in patients with lbbb. Is this true? I have a strong family history of heart disease, my father survived two heart attacks, mother survived double bypass and my maternal uncle died from a heart attack, all were smokers with high cholesterol and high blood pressure. I am a former smoker. I am a 43-year-old female. I have been exercising six days per week for over 20 years. My cholesterol is high 213 but HDL is 140 and triglycerides are low. I am a little put off by a nuclear stress echo and would prefer the regular exercise. But I want to know what this new doctor says is true? Then I guess I will have to go nuclear. I am currently taking Spironolactone 100 mg for acne, Omeprazole, and multivitamins. I just had an ultrasound of heart and EKG past monday. Doctor did not mention anything other than lbbb that was previously diagnosed.
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:
Hello doctor,I was diagnosed with a left branch bundle block a few years back. I have been under the care of a cardiologist to make sure my heart is fine since then. I have done stress echos yearly or every two years since and have been told my heart is otherwise fine. I just had to switch the other doctor because of insurance and my new doctor says old stress echos are irrelevant, that only chemical or nuclear echos work in patients with lbbb. Is this true? I have a strong family history of heart disease, my father survived two heart attacks, mother survived double bypass and my maternal uncle died from a heart attack, all were smokers with high cholesterol and high blood pressure. I am a former smoker. I am a 43-year-old female. I have been exercising six days per week for over 20 years. My cholesterol is high 213 but HDL is 140 and triglycerides are low. I am a little put off by a nuclear stress echo and would prefer the regular exercise. But I want to know what this new doctor says is true? Then I guess I will have to go nuclear. I am currently taking Spironolactone 100 mg for acne, Omeprazole, and multivitamins. I just had an ultrasound of heart and EKG past monday. Doctor did not mention anything other than lbbb that was previously diagnosed.

### Response:Based on the information provided, it seems that your new doctor is correct in stating that only nuclear or chemical stress echos are useful in patients with left branch bundle block (LBBB). This is because LBBB can affect the electrical conduction system of the heart, leading to abnormalities in the EKG results.

Nuclear stress echos involve injecting a small amount of radioactive material into the bloodstream, which allows for visualization of blood flow and the heart's response to stress. Chemical stress echos use a medication that can be used to simulate physical exertion or stress on the heart.

Regular exercise is an important component of managing heart disease, but it may not provide the same level of information as a nuclear or chemical stress echo. These tests can help evaluate the functioning of the heart during physical exertion and provide valuable information about the overall health of the heart.

It is important to follow your doctor's recommendations regarding the need for a nuclear stress echo. This test will help assess your cardiovascular health and determine if any further interventions or treatments are necessary.

Please consult with your doctor to discuss the specific reasons behind the recommendation for a nuclear stress echo and any concerns you may have.

However, it's important to note that many women over 40 have healthy pregnancies and deliveries.

To address your concerns and explore the options available to you, it is recommended to consult with a healthcare provider who

input: Hello doctor,I have a lazy eye. My right eye (sph - 0.50 cyl -0.75 axis 10 degrees) and the left eye is fine. I am 24 years old. I am a web developer, I have to work in front of the computer screen more than 13 hours. Kindly answer the following:What should I do? Do I need to change my profession?Is it curable? What is the treatment?Is there any chance of getting other eye affected?
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

Hello doctor,I have a lazy eye. My right eye (sph - 0.50 cyl -0.75 axis 10 degrees) and the left eye is fine. I am 24 years old. I am a web developer, I have to work in front of the computer screen more than 13 hours. Kindly answer the following:What should I do? Do I need to change my profession?Is it curable? What is the treatment?Is there any chance of getting other eye affected?

### Response:Hello,

Based on the information provided, it seems like you have a condition called strabismus, specifically esotropia (crossed eyes). The deviation of 10 degrees in the axis indicates a significant misalignment.

As a web developer who spends long hours in front of a computer screen, it is important to take breaks and practice good eye care to prevent further strain on your eyes. However, in your case, it would be best to consult an ophthalmologist for a comprehensive evaluation and appropriate treatment.

The treatment for strabismus depends on the underlying cause and severity. It may include:

1. Eye exercises: If the cause is due to weak eye muscles, eye exercises can be prescribed to strengthen the muscles and improve alignment.
2. Eye drops: Medicated eye drops may be prescribed to relax the muscles and improve alignment.
3. Surgery: In some cases, surgery may be recommended to realign the eyes and improve vision.

It is important to note that the treatment plan will depend on the specific diagnosis and individual factors. Therefore, it is crucial to consult with an ophthalmologist who can assess your condition thoroughly and provide personalized recommendations.

Regarding the chance of getting other eye affected, it is possible for strabismus to occur in the other eye

### Response:Hepatitis B is not typically transmitted through saliva. The virus is primarily spread through contact with the blood or other body fluids of an infected person.

The viral load of 1.5 * 10^5 count/mL indicates that you have a high level of hepatitis B virus in your body. This suggests active infection. The cure rate for hepatitis B depends on several factors, including the genotype of the virus and the treatment regimen used.

In general, antiviral medications can help cure hepatitis B infection, especially when started early in the course of the disease. However, it is important to consult with a healthcare professional who can evaluate your specific situation and provide personalized recommendations.

The time it takes to get completely cured can vary depending on various factors such as the treatment regimen, adherence to medication, and individual response to therapy. Generally, it takes several months to a year or longer to achieve sustained virologic response, which is considered a cure.

It is recommended that you consult with a healthcare professional who can assess your condition, perform any necessary tests, and provide appropriate treatment options based on your specific circumstances.

input: Hello doctor,I am writing for my daughter, staying away from us, with her husband. She is 30 years, 5 feet 1 inch and 63 kg, working in the IT sector. She is married for the last three years and seriously trying for conception from a year. She missed her period once in the beginning of this year. During her obstetrics consultation, beta hCG was done. It was repeated after two days. A transvaginal ultrasound scan was done and repeated after 10 days. The end result was diagnosed as a blighted ovum. So, it was evacuated by D and C.Our daughter is of normal build and nutrition. Her menstrual history was normal since the beginning in terms of cycle, duration, and flow. But, one month after D and C, she did not have her period. On the doctor's advice, she took some medicines and bleeding occurred. She was known hypothyroid. So, she was taking Thyroxin 50 or 75 to keep the TSH near about 2.5 Uiu/ml. Her Hb % and sugar are within the normal range.Again, she tried to conceive since three months ago along with Aspirin and folic acid. She missed her period last month. Her beta hCG was 9.20 mIu/ mL. It was repeated after two days. It came down to 1 Miu/ml suggestive of \chemical pregnancy\. This time, after a few days, a spontaneous jelly-like bleeding occurred for two days. I would like to add that her husband requires to take Penegra 50 mg tab before a performance. Our daughter is immunized with triple antigen, polio, MMR, chickenpox and hepatitis B vaccine in childhood. The transvaginal scan (done at a later phase of the first conception) showed normal anatomical and physiological pattern of the ovary and uterus to me at least (report attached).Two consecutive miscarriages brought great disappointment to all. Presently, the doctor told her to take Aspirin 150 mg, folic acid, and Vitamin B12 combination tablet and to try for pregnancy again. I want your valuable opinion regarding subsequent management or the right line of treatment and suggestions or tests (if any) to get a successful pregnancy and healthy baby.

### Response:Based on the symptoms you have described, it is possible that your son is experiencing a condition called "feverfew." Feverfew is a rare disorder characterized by a high fever that primarily affects the head and neck area. The hands and feet may feel cold due to vasodilation (widening of blood vessels) in response to the elevated body temperature.

The exact cause of feverfew is unknown, but it is believed to be related to abnormal immune system responses. It is more commonly seen in children and tends to resolve on its own within a few days without any specific treatment.

To manage your son's symptoms, you can try the following:
1. Encourage him to drink plenty of fluids to prevent dehydration.
2. Dress him in light clothing to help keep his body temperature down.
3. Use a cool mist humidifier in his room to add moisture to the air.
4. Administer over-the-counter pain relievers such as acetaminophen or ibuprofen to alleviate any discomfort.

If his symptoms worsen or persist beyond a few days, it would be advisable to consult with his pediatrician for further evaluation and guidance.
